Customers are more demanding and informed, question the fees and the added value of various services in the financial sector. The primacy of the client attracted big techs, such as Facebook that wants to enter Portugal in banking, but also fintech, which can be allied with the incumbent bank. If we already see Facebook asking for a bank license to operate in Portugal and Google investing heavily in fintech, then it's time to act, "says João Freire de Andrade, president of Portugal Fintech." In countries where online retailing is "tech players, such as Apple, Google, Amazon and Facebook in the United States, and Alibaba, Baidu and Tencent in China," Fabio Panetta, governor of Italy.





For Nuno Fernandes, dean of the Catholic Lisbon School of Business & Economics and Professor of Finance, this emergence of fintechs and big techs is related to the fact that, in the financial business, a "customer centricity" , which is also called the C2B era (consumer-to-business).



Customer Experiences



"Big techs have two major differentiating factors regarding customer relationships and requirements," says João Freire de Andrade, who is also head of BiG Start Ventures. The first is recurrence, "every day, in the course of your life, people pass in the way of these companies." Therefore, "it is very easy for the end customer to choose one of these companies as their personal ecosystem, since they can do everything they need in one site already used every day."



The second factor relates to the fact that these companies have a very large "user experience" budget, "becoming specialists in digital contact and the creation of an optimal experience, which contributes to a easier to attract the customer, "concludes João Freire de Andrade.



Changing consumer profiles also helps. "Consumers - especially those in their 20s and 30s - are increasingly receptive to their banking services being provided by a nontraditional financial services company," said an Accenture report, Beyond The Everyday Bank, on the transformation of digital banking brought about by big tech, or techfin.



Alliance against the giants



"As a result of the financial collapse and the serious consequences for the world economy, customers (both private and business) became more demanding, more informed, questioning the fees charged to them and the real added value of in the opposite direction, Fintechs appear much faster, dynamic, cheap and highly oriented to respond quickly and efficiently to customer requirements, "says Nuno Fernandes.



The incumbents, the traditional banks, are going to have to change. The strategy that "should be followed", according to Nuno Fernandes, "is the collaboration between banks and fintech.

This collaboration is essential for the future of innovation in financial services. In this way, traditional financial institutions can complete the talent and technology gap and fintech gain structure to develop their business. "



"More than 75% of fintech's businesses have as their primary business objective to collaborate with traditional financial services," said Anirban Bose, Head of Business UnitCapgemini Global Financial Services Strategy at the World FinTech Report 2018 presentation.



Perfect combination



"For the incumbent bank, the strategy must be three-dimensional: to integrate, co-create and invest with technological companies," says João Freire de Andrade. In their view, "start-ups often appear on the market not to replace but to complement incumbent service with a greater focus on the end customer and a specific problem. By integrating these services into the offering incumbents can solve many problems that the consumer detects in their relationship with the bank. "



On the other hand, for fintech, "incumbent banking can be a strong candidate for data storage as it incorporates a solid and secure structure," which solves one of the "open API" problems, which is where they should be stored data complying with the general data protection regulation.



They can combine the advantages of each partner. "Fintech is redefining customer experience in the financial sector through a technology-driven and customer-centric approach, while Fintech can benefit from the greater level of confidence customers still have with traditional banking," he says. the director of Catholic.



The long-term success of fintech and financial institutions depends on this collaboration, even to find suitable business models "in a context of greater customer demand and greater competition, such as big tech", concludes Nuno Fernandes

urn:contentItem:5Y55-YJ21-JB5M-W0YM-00000-00Banco de Espana: Multilateralism and globalisation reforms2020-01-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:17ZLexisNexisBanco de Espana: Multilateralism and globalisation reforms

Jan. 28 -- Banco de Espana issued the following Speech:

- Presentation of the book Excesos: Amenazas a la prosperidad global, by Emilio Ontiveros

Good evening

Honourable Minister and Authorities, ladies and gentlemen.

It is an honour to be here at the presentation of Professor Emilio Ontiveros's book Excesos: Amenazas a la prosperidad global (Excesses: Threats to global prosperity), and to share some thoughts with you on the subjects it addresses.

As has habitually been the case in his extensive academic and popularised work, Professor Ontiveros hits the nail on the head in his analysis of one of the main challenges posed by the current international landscape: the characterisation of and the risks associated with the economic and financial globalisation witnessed in recent decades. His work is immense, as it requires deep-seated knowledge of the wealth of interrelated factors that shape the highly complex and changing economic, political and social situation at present. As is also habitual for the author, he is successful in his venture: he presents a profound and well-structured analysis of the issue. And one that is, moreover, reader-friendly and comprehensible. Our congratulations, Emilio.

1. The book's main line of argument

As Professor Ontiveros rightly says, the globalisation and growing openness of economies to the flow of trade, finance, persons and knowledge, lauded by many just some years back as the fundamental driver of global economic development, is now questioned by significant economic, political and social agents, at least in its current form.

Among the causes behind this, the author highlights how the opening up and globalisation of economic relations has promoted the rise of new emerging powers - with China to the fore - on the global stage. These powers are significant not only economically, but also politically and geo-strategically. This has resulted in the growing complexity of global governance and in a rivalry that currently threatens to break the multilateral arrangements in force since the Second World War. We should recall that Chinese membership of the WTO was not accompanied by a parallel process involving its transformation towards a market economy. Indeed, China retained high export subsidies, was hardly open to foreign investment and pursued industrial and technological policies that distorted international relations. This has prompted continuous complaints by the Western powers.

Partly, one of the arguments behind the protectionist reaction led most recently by the United States has been the WTO's inability to correct these distortions. Yet it should be stressed that the US shift towards bilateralism in international relations has significant consequences, beyond merely trade considerations, that stretch to the struggle for leadership of technological developments and, more generally, to an effort to sustain a privileged position in the economic and political arenas. The United States is not an isolated case in the shift. And undoubtedly bilateralism, linked in part to free market economy constraints, has gained weight recently in how other nations operate globally.

In any event, as the author points out, what is true is that the shift to protectionist-style policies - commercially and geopolitically - threatens to break the multilateral global governance arrangements in force. Paradoxically, the United States had led these arrangements over recent decades. Now, there is a consequent danger for global prosperity. The redistribution of power among a growing number of players entails the replacement of the multilateral international cooperation arrangements with a new, more fragmented, decentralised and informal system as regards decision-making, in which bilateral and regional solutions trump multilateral agreements.

Another characteristic feature of globalisation recently has been the onrush of the digital revolution and the roll-out of new communication and information technologies. These are driving radical changes in the economy, in society, in how we understand labour relations and in investment and consumption decisions.

As the author indicates in the book, we are yet to fully discern the possibilities that artificial intelligence, robotisation and quantum computing can offer in the different facets of our lives. Professor Ontiveros also emphasises the risks and threats the application of these new technologies entails, e.g. the control of individuals, the invasion of privacy, the concentration of market power in the Big Tech companies, inequality and the exclusion of those who fail to adapt.

Adding to globalisation and technical change is the demographic challenge. This poses fundamental challenges to growth, productivity and the sustainability of public finances in numerous economies. Migratory problems and those arising from unstoppable urbanisation have also become priorities given their implications for economic, social and environmental development.

With all these ingredients, the author's main line of argument in the book is that globalisation, bound up with intense technological changes and the deregulation of economies, has contributed to generating uneven economic growth, a prevalence of the financial over the real economy, a concentration of market power in major corporations (which has stifled competition) and a deterioration in the environment.

These are the "excesses" to which the title of the book refers. And, according to Professor Ontiveros, they must be tackled by reformulating the capitalist system and the multilateral governance framework. With this reformulation, Professor Ontiveros suggests governments and public institutions should play a more active role when regulatorily mitigating market failings and oversee compliance with the rules. In his view, that would also serve to ensure the use and efficient, but fair, distribution of resources along with more inclusive and sustainable growth.

Presentation

SERGIO GÃ¡MEZ MARTÃ­NEZ, GLOBAL HEAD OF SHAREHOLDER & IR, BANCO SANTANDER, S.A.: Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining. This is Sergio GÃ¡mez, Global Head of Investor Relations at Santander. And obviously, thank you for attending our Investor Day.

As you can see from the agenda, we have a very busy morning ahead with presentations and fireside chats from the group -- some of the group's senior management. Obviously, we will kick off the Investor Day with the Banco Santander Group Executive Chairman, Ana BotÃ­n; and our Group CEO, José Antonio Ãlvarez; then we will have a Q&A session to which our Group CFO, José Antonio Cantera, will also participate. Then after the coffee break, in the second half, we will discuss some of the key issues shaping the growth of our business such as Latin America growth and our supertankers or core banks with Sergio Rial, CEO of Santander Brazil; and Dirk Marzluf, Global Head of IT and Ops. And obviously, as well, we will discuss on additional fireside chat the digital transformation with Lindsey Argalas, our Innovation Officer; and the CEO of Openbank, Ezequiel Szafir.

Just to let you know, we wanted to use today not just to give you a great PowerPoint presentation but also to take the opportunity about how our digital investments is capturing market growth and give you the chance to see the solutions and hear from the teams that are delivering them. And that's why you saw 7 booths in total. And you can get a couple minutes demo talking different market segment, all of them with a flexible and a scalable solution that actively is bringing to life our vision of becoming the best open financial services platform and earning the lasting loyalty of our customers. Please take the opportunity to go over to the booths during the lunch.

That's all for me now. So now over to Ana. Thank you.

ANA BOTÃ­N SANZ DE SAUTUOLA Y O'SHEA, GROUP EXECUTIVE CHAIRMAN, BANCO SANTANDER, S.A.: So good morning, and welcome to our Investor Day. I will start by basically reviewing briefly our strategy. As we said, we are not going to be changing our strategy. We are going to be presenting you our next 3-year, 4-year plan, our medium-term plan. And so it's important to remind ourselves what it is that we set out to do 3 years ago when we presented in October 2015.

We are focused on earning the lasting loyalty of our people, our customers, our shareholders and communities. And we have refined our aim. As a bank, we want to be the best open financial services platform, and we want to do that and earn the lasting loyalty of all our stakeholders by doing everything in a way that is simple and personal and fair.

And really at the base of all we do and our success, not just today and in the past but going forward, is embedding this culture across the organization. And this loyalty strategy is paramount for our sustainable profitability growth over the coming years. It's a virtuous circle you can see in there. If our people are more committed, they will do an extra effort for our customers, who will give us their business more and more, and this will be good for you -- for us, for you, all of us, our shareholders, and would be able to support our communities in a better way.

So in terms of how we've been doing this over the last 3 years. As you know, we have an -- please take advantage of this because they're all here. We have incorporated a lot of new people over the last -- basically in '14 and '15, we have -- we put in place new CEOs in Brazil, Mexico, U.K., Spain, the U.S. We have a new Head of IT and Ops, new Head of Santander Digital, Head of Risk, Wealth Management, Openbank. And of course, as you know, we refreshed our board and our internal governance. And this is super important because this is what has truly given us support for the strategy.

And we have been focusing on 2 key fronts, earning the loyalty of our customers, becoming the bank of choice; but also very important and you'll hear more about that today, accelerating our digital transformation and providing our customers a seamless experience across all our channels, whether physical or digital. And all of this with a goal of growth, profitability and increasing strength of our balance sheet.

At the core of the strategy, as I said, you've seen this before so I will not spend a lot of time, but really at the core of our strategy is earning more loyal customers. We have a big customer base, lots of active customers. Earning the loyalty of more and more of these customers is essential because they're more profitable, they have higher revenues, and this is also true for digital customers. Very important, and this is a big difference with most of our European peers, we have grown our revenues over the last 3 years.

Second, profitability. And there is more to do. I will get on to that and José Antonio also. But we have done a -- we've made a big progress on the profitability front. You can see here all our geographies in the group. Our return on risk-weighted assets has gone from 1.2% to 1.55%. Very importantly in 2015, only 40% of our capital was invested above our cost of equity. Today, that is 90%. And obviously, we aim to do more than that. And very important, we have invested in value-creating acquisitions that help us in the transformation of our model. Buying back some core businesses that we had sold, but very importantly through some add-on acquisitions, obviously Popular is maybe a bit more than that, but -- and divestitures. So it's not just about acquiring, it's about selling when it's not core or they're not performing, and you have the list there. At the end, the net of those 2 is a net buying, and you'll see -- I will show you the numbers later.

We are focusing on the profitability not just of our countries, but we have been focusing a lot also on the profitability by segments. So this is the only way to maximize profitability. We're not going to invest forever even if the country is very profitable in segments or businesses that do not deliver within a period of time, and this is also helping us on this quest for profitability.

So you can see here, if you take the benchmark of the 1.2% we started in 2015, that we've gone from 80% to 30% of our risk-weighted assets being above this 1.2% cutoff. As an example, for example, within the U.S., we have shifted assets from SBNA in terms of growth to Santander Consumer. And in many other countries, this is happening, where we're actually investing more in certain segments than in others according to the profitability targets that we have set ourselves.

Finally, on strength, José Antonio will cover in more detail what we have done and what we intend to do in the future. We are generating a lot of organic capital. You can see over this period, EUR 25 billion plus. As I explained perimeter, ex Popular, we've invested EUR 2.3 billion. We have given back to shareholders and AT1 holders EUR 12.8 billion. And the organic generation after dividends would be a bit more than EUR 10 billion. So with the capital increase in 2015, we have added net to our capital base close to EUR 18 billion over this time period.

And finally, in terms of our final profitability to shareholders or returns to shareholders. As you know, the new team has focused and will continue to focus on earnings per share and tangible NAV per share plus dividend -- cumulative dividends. If you look at the returns without FX, which is truly what is under our control, we delivered 55% increase over this period and 41% tangible NAV plus cumulative dividends. If you look in euros at the end, it's 22% and 27%. Clearly, FX has been a drag on our results, and we intend to continue improving. We're not happy where our share price is, obviously, but we have outperformed in this period the benchmark of European banks.

I would like to spend now a few minutes, and this is important for the future, which is how is Santander as a group of businesses, where do we stand in terms of the competitive environment? Why can we succeed? And why do we have as a management team the confidence that our strategy will continue to work? And this is very important to understand for the future, so I am going to spend a few slides on this.

The first thing is that we have scale. It's not just global scale. It's in-market scale, and this is a key, I'd say, foundation for everything that you're going to be hearing in the next few hours.

The second is diversification. We have 10 core markets in Europe and the Americas. Not just that, across developed and developing markets. And this is what is leading to a more predictable and growing earnings profile than other banks. This is 20-year data, but it works for the last 4 or 5 years. It's Bloomberg. It's the EPS quarterly volatility, 9% for Santander, 140% for our peers. These are the best and biggest banks in the world. The net income increase for Santander has been 5x, and that is 3x the peer average. This is, of course, what is allowing us to deliver through the cycle.

Openbank has been mentioned in -- this morning quite a few times. What is really what Openbank adds to the group?

EZEQUIEL SZAFIR HOLCMAN, CEO, OPENBANK S.A.: That's a very good question. Actually, I think Openbank adds to the group in different areas. And the questions they asked early, I think, go in that direction. The first one is when we talk about the platform. So Openbank is developing a full banking platform that is based on the new partings of machine learning, one single data lake for everything. It's cloud based. The core banking is new and modular. One of the modules, as Dirk said, is Temenos, but it's like 42 modules. And that's a bit the seed of the future for the group. It's a -- somehow, for Lindsey and Dirk, also a partner to develop the know-how and the R&D that then we will be applying at the group. It's -- really if you would be a car company living on diesel sales every quarter, you want to have your own electric car built and properly done in-house that runs the right number of miles and that can charge in less than 4 hours. That's why we are doing well like the Tesla for the group in that sense.

Besides the technology, I think another very important thing we do is the -- there is this art of doing what others do without branches, right? This is -- if you think about it, for example, somehow, Amazon does what Tesla does, what Walmart does but without a store. So we are kind of doing what banks do without branches. And that means that we should be able to attract customers, engage them and retain them in a full digital way without branches. That's probably a lot how the future will look like and having within the group a bank that is doing that every day with already a 1.2 million customers and engage -- 38% engaged with a resulting EUR 9.5 billion deposits. That's, I think, a big added value.

SERGIO GÃ¡MEZ MARTÃ­NEZ: Okay. Lindsey, one of the pushbacks that every now and then when I meet with investors we have on the speedboats is that the speedboat as such is a very nice concept. But in the bigger scheme of things for the group, they don't make the difference, right? So what can we tell to the audience on that? How long should be expect until this really -- speedboats make a difference for the group?

LINDSEY TYLER ARGALAS, CHIEF DIGITAL & INNOVATION OFFICER, BANCO SANTANDER, S.A.: Right. Well, you're right, Sergio. Today, the speedboats relative to the core business are relatively small because they're fairly early stage. However, we think that there's huge potential. One of the ways that we prioritize the speedboats is we take very large problem phases that we feel are ripe for drastic improvement or disruption that we feel we're uniquely placed to solve. As you heard Ana talk about them, we see in the midterm we actually expect that we'll have 15 million active customers using these services. Most of those we anticipate to be new to the franchise. So again, if we think about driving customer growth, that's pretty significant to the bank.

Very importantly, though, is we don't just look at it in terms of acquiring new customers. We look very methodically at making sure that those are active customers, they're getting value from the service, they're transacting with that solution. And as a result, that they are not only getting value themselves, but it's delivering value for Santander as well. So that's very important and very different than many of the startups you see today which are just chasing user numbers and Ana mentioned that a few times.

The last thing I'll say is of course it takes time to build that very large, scalable digital business. But in the interim, as the technology comes online, we're taking some of those services and applying them to our core business. One Pay FX is an excellent example. We invested in the infrastructure and modern technology and modern services, and we put the One Pay FX, the international transfer capability, into the Spain mobile banking app, for example. Since we launched that, there has been a 120% incremental transactions and cross-border payments, right? So while we're incubating a stand-alone digital business that will allow us to acquire new customers, the core business is also benefiting as well.

SERGIO GÃ¡MEZ MARTÃ­NEZ: And Eze, what -- I mean, investors and analysts tell me or tell us that most of banks have some kind of a digital online platform. So the first question is, what does Openbank make different? So why Openbank is different versus other bank competitors? EZEQUIEL SZAFIR HOLCMAN: So let me answer the first question. It's -- I think it's more fun because it's a question I get asked a lot, and there was a difference between Openbank and other digital banks that we have across Europe. I think, first, there are a lot of similarities. So if you see European large digital banks, we have a lot of similarities. We are -- well, we're fully digital. We are razor-sharp focused on customer service and support. We have a beautifully looking app. We have a double-digit growth on mostly every KPI. But toward the end there, the 2 big differences are, on the one hand, the broad portfolio. Most digital banks would stop at having one app and, at current, take on probably a debit card or a credit card. Openbank has everything that your bank doesn't have or we have the same. You have a great looking app. You could do -- for example, if somebody here has an Openbank account, you are already probably keeping your passwords and your secret notes within the app. If we keep your money, why can't we keep, as a data bank, your data? You probably also are aggregating and seeing the balance of other banks. So we're making full use of PSA, too. So within our clients, within their app, they can see the balance of any other bank or even of PayPal, for example. So all these goodies that digital banks have, we have. But then we have the proper banking service, right? So you can get a loan, you can finance your payment. Your school keeps tuition right away from your app in 2 clicks. And we have a full broker. The brokerage is a open architecture. You can buy and sell stocks, futures, warrants, whatever you want. We have robo-advisory combined with micro-investing and similar-type things. I like it. So you do have all those services that are not just going to be deployed. They're deployed. They are working. We have already EUR 1.2 billion in assets under management. So that's a big difference.

And then this -- the big enabler for that, a difference, which is the business model. Our business model is banking, retail banking, meaning we do what other banks do without branches. So the result is that because having all those services, we have, for example, the average customer has about EUR 21,000 of balance, average balance. If you look at other digital banks, they probably are in -- or GBP 200 one, the other one is in what, EUR 1,000. So it's a real relationship we have with them.

We have mortgages. We have started the mortgages a few months ago. We're already over EUR 400 million in mortgages. Mortgages are, in average, less leveraged than the market, which is very good. So I think it's a big difference to other banks.

And that is why value-add stays in the group, because the whole technology development process is not isolated. It's done together with the technology group, with the digital group. Some stuff that we work at Openbank, for example, we -- I think AML is a big point. If you see what other digital banks are doing, because they are -- most of them are owned or -- by venture capital, so probably, I think, is -- they're investing in -- AML is very expensive. And you will not get a payback in the next 3 years, right? With our bank, we're a regulated bank. We're part of the Group Santander. We do the proper thing. But we're developing in parallel -- actually, it's Lindsey's team developing for us a whole machine learning base with our digital intelligence, AML tool. That AML tool was developed by Lindsey's team, deployed first at Openbank as an R&D lab. It was run in parallel, worked really well. And now Dirk's team is rolling it out in 3 countries, including Europe and America. So that's how the value goes from one place to the other.

SERGIO GÃ¡MEZ MARTÃ­NEZ: Thank you. And Lindsey, a similar question to the one that I asked before to Dirk, how does innovation add value from Madrid, the corporate center to the subsidiaries?

LINDSEY TYLER ARGALAS: Well, I think, as Eze just touched on a couple of them, I would say first of all, in terms of expertise, right, so it doesn't make sense for all of our countries to have deep expertise in data advanced analytics, artificial intelligence, Blockchain, a practice called conversion rate optimization. Dirk mentioned a couple on data artificial intelligence. Eze just gave one example as well. But we basically have 100 data scientists who work very closely with the country, looking for the highest-impact use cases. We have a global machine learning platform. We developed the algorithms once, and they get deployed locally, running on that country's data. So again, very high return on investment. If you think about the improvements we're seeing with 30% churn reduction, 20% improvement in cross-sells, 40% AML, reduction on false positive, so there's a number of things, again, where you take out expertise and we deploy it locally. Similarly, a lot of the tech companies and e-commerce players have a discipline that is well worn, which is called conversion rate optimization. It is a deep science and a deep practice that has huge implications as more of our customers shop online. And so over the last year, we've been working with most of the countries and now this year working with all the countries, where we've seen improvements of 2x in the conversion rate, which is driving a lot more of our sales and, again, efficiencies in our sales channel process, right? So the expertise is critical.

The second big theme is around shared development. And so Ana gave one example earlier of Globile, which is our code name for the mobile banking app. We saw about 9 months ago that most of our countries wanted to bring very similar functionality and innovations to their mobile banking experience so that they can have the best experience possible. We see now that an average mobile banking user is accessing and logging in 19 times a month. And that's a tremendous opportunity for us to engage and add value in those interactions. And so in a matter of months, a cross-country team basically built several components and functionality, and they're now deployed already in the hands of 9 million of our mobile customers with very ambitious road map for the rest of the year. And so again, we're going to see a lot more of the shared development where it makes sense. All of the new speedboats and the opportunities we talked about in global trade services, global merchant services, they will all be built as global platforms and shared across the country. So that's -- and that's a big change.

That being said, the other difference is that today, if you look at our cost structure where we invest, we are anything but ideal or -- because we are investing a lot on stuff that then is there. You don't -- we are a -- we're going to open in other countries, and we need probably, in some countries, one person, a market manager. In other countries, we may need 50, 80 people. That's like a whole country. So that's how digital business works.

SERGIO GÃ¡MEZ MARTÃ­NEZ: Alvaro?

ALVARO SERRANO SAENZ DE TEJADA: Alvaro Serrano from Morgan Stanley. Openbank -- another question for -- on Openbank. It's existed for a while, and I understand there's a lot of development. As for non-European countries, we can operate. We have a full stack with our local license. We have applied for licenses in several countries already. Some of those applications became public. We have already started assembling a team in Argentina. We hired -- the country manager for Google is now our country manager in Argentina. We have a team already, 10 people in -- and we're going to open as well there. So it's happening, it's coming.

BENJIE CREELAN-SANDFORD, BANK ANALYST, JEFFERIES LLC, RESEARCH DIVISION: It's Benjie at Jefferies. Just a question on credit risk management. I mean, how does that work in terms of the information flow or how that's managed at the group level between Openbank and the traditional banks within Santander? And what implications also does that have in terms of your ability or your willingness to scale up quickly in new markets where the traditional subsidiaries aren't operating?

EZEQUIEL SZAFIR HOLCMAN: Yes, that's I think a very good question. And if I may start by a personal reflection. I joined Santander about 3 years ago. I came from Amazon. And from outside, you tend to see banks with large corporations like not expecting much on the digital side, right, or on the technology side. And when you come -- when I came at least to Santander, the surprise is that actually, if you go around countries, you will find extremely strong groups of data scientists working on machine learning algorithms, precisely on credit scoring and risk in countries like Brazil, Mexico, Argentina, Spain. We have the best of both worlds. The group has a central know-how team for modeling, and we are running in parallel many times the old-fashioned rules based. We algorithm the new one. We test. We do testing. We do actually real-life testing. We take 2,000 clients. We try and we compare with pilot groups. And that can be directly applied into countries. And we work a lot together. There's just a -- so the only limitation you have is ensuring data because of the data protection lock. But most only to share data. I mean, an algorithm is actually a pen drive, and you can go and put an algorithm in any data and then you optimize it, right? So it's a joint work. And we are, as we speak, the -- there is a central function in Lindsey's team for machine learning, there is a team scientist at Openbank and we work together. It's sharing -- actually we met in Madrid last week. It's a club. They meet and they exchange algorithms, ideas, et cetera. The robot for machine learning development of Openbank is already working in Santander Argentina, for example.

SERGIO GÃ¡MEZ MARTÃ­NEZ: No more questions, I guess, so I guess we can leave it here, and I'll leave the floor to Ana for her concluding remarks. Thank you.

ANA BOTÃ­N SANZ DE SAUTUOLA Y O'SHEA: So thank you very much, everybody, for being with us today. I'll just be very brief so we can all have lunch and have a chance to talk some more. I hope you had enough time for questions, but you will have more time during lunch.

So as we have explained during this morning, the customer loyalty and digital strategy is working for us. It has allowed us to deliver on our 3-year plan. We have done that leveraging on our strong foundations, which we covered. And really, the whole focus and a lot of the focus going forward will remain in terms of net -- the network value, the knowledge, the talent and working more together as a single platform. This is super important, and we believe this is the way to deliver not just today -- and this is -- as I said in the Q&A, it's finding the balance between delivering today and in the medium term. And we're aiming to deliver in growth, in profitability and, of course, as a bank, in increased strength as a whole.

So the focus today has been on how we're going to speed up this transformation of Santander to meet the challenges we face, the digital challenges, and the macro and so on. But one of the things that I mentioned briefly in response to a question was that organization is one of the key levers that we have to deliver on strategy and deliver on our plans. And we will continue to focus on robust governance. This is crucial. We have strengthened our internal governance systems and continue to do that. We also need clear lines of accountability, and this is important. And we need really a structure that allows the tough questions and then executes. And this is the reason why we are taking the step which is, for the Santander Group, quite an important one.

We need to continue to make the most of our geographical expertise. Our country leaders are hugely important to us. Diversity is hugely important to us. And we today operate across 3 regions where our business can work much better together. We're doing a lot of that as my colleagues explained a few minutes ago. We need to work in an agile and efficient way, building on each market's strength and innovation. At the end of the day, we do not need to invent the same widget 10 times, sometimes even 20 times. And this is exactly what it is that we are aiming to do.

I must say that one of the questions I often get, José Antonio, José and Sergio also, and one of the questions that really, let's say, I don't get upset because I shouldn't, but I take this on as a constructive challenges, but you're a federation of banks. You're a conglomerate. Well, to prove that we do listen, this is also our response. We want to be less of a conglomerate, less of a federation of banks, and unlock even more the value that we see that the market has not fully recognized. And this is the answer to that. So we are going from many different countries managed, I'd say, autonomously. We will continue, I said that very clearly, in terms of capital and liquidity and responsibility to the local regulators. But the reporting line will change, and this is important because we believe this is a more efficient organization. So we'll have 3 groups of countries, Europe as a geography, South America and North America. Each of the new heads will report to José Antonio, and each of the country heads will report to the new group heads.

Obviously, one of the key goals, and I want to stress this, is that we will not create regional structures. That's not what we're doing. We're going to leverage the group functions, which are very strong, to deliver better for the countries. And as my colleagues, Dirk and Lindsey, explained is, we will have certain centers of excellence in different countries. So this coordination between countries and the center will be strengthened. There will be no new functions being put in place. This will be complemented by a new management committee chaired by our CEO, which will have 12 members, I mentioned that already, 7 nationalities and very much more business focused, again with a very strong -- continuing strong compliance and risk functions across the group. So we believe this is one of the really new things and tools in terms of how we can deliver faster execution. I've been saying that for a while. We have done a lot these 3 years, but we do think Santander has much more potential, a huge opportunity going forward in this digital environment. We believe we will be one of the winners.

So as a summary, I would like to leave you with our medium-term goals. You've seen that already. We are going to collaborate increasingly in a smart way across the group. We're aiming to be the best for our customers. There's no other way in today's world. The best customer experience. This will lead us to the profitability and capital efficiency that we're aiming for and, of course, the simplified management structure to accelerate execution.

So thank you all again for being with us, and we look forward to talking to you. I hope you agree with me after listening to my colleagues we have more like them. We have an amazing team. We have an amazing combination of new talent with the traditional Santander bankers. I think Eze, he comes from Amazon, and I think his team reflects what you can see in Santander Spain or Brazil or the U.K., which is a very unique combination of traditional bankers with new skills. And this is what's going to make us succeed. It's our team.

And I would like to say thank you to everybody here. I'm super proud of what you've done, and I look forward to even more ahead. Thank you again.

urn:contentItem:5WB0-JDR1-JCMP-50NR-00000-00Bancos nacionales piden al BCRA que salga a regular a Mercado Libre2019-06-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:16ZLexisNexisBancos nacionales piden al BCRA que salga a regular a Mercado LibreMARIANOGORODISCH


“Las denominadas big techs están en condiciones de ofrecer varios servicios financieros. Este grupo está compuesto por Google, Amazon, Facebook y Apple, entre las norteamericanas, y por el gigante chino Alibaba. En el mercado regional, Mercado Libre es una big tech. Este tipo de fintech se caracteriza por poseer una base de clientes, con información propia y relevante, que podría ser y es utilizada para la provisión de servicios financieros, no estando disponible para el resto del mercado”, esto dice en el documento realizado por FIEL que el presidente de Adeba, Javier Bolzico, le presentó a Guido Sandleris y al Poder Ejecutivo.


Adicionalmente, a diferencia del resto de las fintechs, en particular las plataformas de marketplace, éstas pueden ofrecer servicios financieros tales como préstamos y también cuentas (virtuales) de depósitos al mismo tiempo. El paper señala que las jurisdicciones más avanzadas en materia regulatoria (por ejemplo, Reino Unido y Australia) han diseñado esquemas ad-hoc para las fintechs, a través de distintos instrumentos. Estos instrumentos son los areneros regulatorios (“sandboxes”), los “hubs” de innovación, los aceleradores y el desarrollo de un modelo de Banca Abierta (“Open Banking”).
Los areneros regulatorios otorgan permisos a bajo costo a los innovadores para proveer nuevos servicios, en un contexto controlado de riesgos. Los “hubs” de innovación buscan facilitar la inserción en la actual regulación de las nuevas firmas, a través del diálogo y el conocimiento de las nuevas tecnologías por parte del regulador. Los aceleradores intentan premiar las innovaciones, incluso con ayuda financiera, para incentivar la aparición de nuevos servicios. Finalmente, el modelo de Banca Abierta busca hacer competir a todos los oferentes, bancos y fintechs, a través del intercambio digital de información de cuentas de los clientes, minimizando los costos de transacción o “switching costs” para la migración de los clientes hacia diversas instituciones.
“Cabe señalar que estos esquemas son mecanismos de transición, con lo que la regulación podría cambiar con el tiempo y en particular respecto de empresas u oferentes que dejan de cumplir con condiciones donde se les otorga cierto carácter experimental. En la Argentina, el BCRA ha avanzado en forma importante en la creación de un “hub” de innovación y en un modelo de acelerador. En cambio, no existen reglas que determinen cómo deben introducirse nuevos productos al mercado ni mediciones del impacto en términos de riesgos. Es decir, no se aplica el concepto de arenero que hoy la mayoría de los reguladores bancarios del mundo están adoptando o intentando adoptar. Tampoco se aplica un modelo de Banca Abierta en la Argentina, aunque debe reconocerse que el desarrollo de este sistema puede ser muy costoso y que podría recurrirse a un sustituto como la portabilidad de datos en forma estandarizada. En términos generales, debería tenerse presente que, aunque las fintechs no son una parte significativa del mercado financiero, los organismos internacionales recomiendan a los reguladores del sistema financiero, en vista a su rápida evolución, tener en consideración a estas firmas en sus evaluaciones de riesgo y en los marcos regulatorios”, sugiere el estudio.

urn:contentItem:5WC8-1PJ1-JDVW-N0VJ-00000-00Banco Votorantim COO on the risks and opportunities of fintech2019-06-14T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:16ZLexisNexisQ&AExclusiveBanco Votorantim COO on the risks and opportunities of fintechDavid Feliba

The bank has a fintech lab dedicated to screening the sector and elevating business cases to senior management, frequently resulting in acquisition. Banco Votorantim already has 15 partnerships with fintech companies in Brazil.

Banco Votorantim has a fintech lab dedicated to screening the sector and elevating business cases to senior management, frequently resulting in acquisition.

A steady increase in the use of mobile devices has correlated with a spike in cybersecurity incidents. The country's open banking initiative is expected to increase risks.

At the Ciab conference in São Paulo, Brazil, banking executives are clamoring to build upon the partnerships with financial technology companies that are becoming increasingly ubiquitous across the sector. Most say they are looking keenly at startups that can help their banks gain agility and client-knowledge.

Among those in attendance is Marcelo Clara, COO and chief information officer at Banco Votorantim SA, a Brazilian institution co-owned by state-run Banco do Brasil SA and Votorantim SA, the Latin American industrial conglomerate. The bank's fintech partnerships include Olvia, which uses artificial intelligence to provide financial assistance, as well as online student loan lender Pravaler and online auto marketplace Carflix. However, Clara believes that blockchain technology has the potential to have the greatest impact on the banking space in the future.

S&P Global Market Intelligence recently sat down with Clara on the sidelines of the Ciab conference, where he is one of the keynote speakers.

What follows is an edited transcript of that discussion.

Marcelo Clara, COO and chief information officer at Banco Votorantim

What has been the bank's recent strategy regarding technology?

Marcelo Clara: It is impossible nowadays to think of an enterprise, whatever the size, without tech. Technology is at the core of every company in any kind of industry. We started 3 years ago with a huge investment from IT in infrastructure, architecture, and modernization of our legacy [business]. Besides that, we also invested a lot in culture from the C-level along with the HR department and we can now see the results. We are seen by fintechs and other institutions as a financial institution that has been modernized, and we have positioned ourselves as one of the banks that really partners with fintechs. We can now say it is an asset that we have created, an environment not only to retain talent but to attract it as well. Fifteen fintechs are either invested by us or connected to our business through our IT platform.

How does this process of picking fintechs work?

We launched our lab one year ago. There is an internal committee where the C-level discusses strategy and defines the priorities aligned to our vision. Once we have agreed on that, we give the challenge to the lab to understand and map the market and do the proof of concepts with fintechs. Later on, they show us what they have identified and tested and present us with business cases. Some of them are approved and implemented. And at that point, we have different ways of doing so. Sometimes it is just a partnership, and in some cases we invest in them through our own venture capital [fund]. We use these different tools to understand and maximize the value that we can get from the entire ecosystem.

What are the weak spots these companies are actually filling?

We have many cases. It's a very interesting marriage. We have a lot of knowledge and capability; we understand regulation and governance. A partnership with them allows us to interchange their ability to understand the customer in a different way, from a more flexible, less bureaucratic approach. Using different technologies that large organizations were often not allowed to use, more tied to big tech companies that could supply them. Nowadays it's different. We have to maximize their ability to understand the client's need.

Digital channels have consolidated in Brazil as the preferred channel for customers, with 60% of transactions in 2018 being carried out either by internet or mobile banking. What does that mean for cybersecurity concerns? Are incidents increasing?

Yes, they are. It is one of the issues the whole industry has to face every day. We have to rise to the challenge. Once you are more open and we now have open banking coming when you become more digital and hyperconnected, of course, you have a lot of new ports in terms of risk that you have to manage. This is already happening, and all the institutions like us need to invest in cybersecurity. It is a considerable cost, and we have also increased our investment there over the past years.

Is it your responsibility to educate customers?

Yes, we have to invest in education to prevent fraud and social engineering, since most of the cases that we've seen have come from the social aspect rather than the hard tech approach.

In your view, what is the correct approach for a bank in Brazil that seeks to remain technologically competitive?

The challenge is to have equilibrium in terms of control and flexibility. If you become more controlled, more risk-resistant, at the end of the day, you will be less flexible. On the other hand, if you are too flexible ... you will not be able to manage all the risk and compliance and regulatory issues. The banks that will succeed in the future will understand how to maximize these two aspects.

urn:contentItem:5WHY-T4M1-JBCN-40DT-00000-00'Ban Facial Recognition' campaign kickstarts -- but in futility2019-07-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:16ZLexisNexisRAPID REACTIONS'Ban Facial Recognition' campaign kickstarts -- but in futilityCheryl K. Chumley

A group called Fight for the Future has just launched a campaign calling for a national ban on government's use of facial recognition technology.

The call, at BanFacialRecognition.com, may be justified.

But honestly, that's one genie that's not going back into the lamp any time soon.

Police, airline personnel, military officials, federal authorities, security folks, even retailers and corporate world execs these are all forces that say they need the technology in order to keep America safe.

As founders themselves warned: the line between liberty and security is a thin one. Once the tradeoffs start, they're hard to stop.

And in America, the ratchet toward security at the expense of individual liberty really began post-Sept. 11, when Americans, by and large, were in a panic.

Technology, however, adds a new element one that privacy advocates see as a massive threat, filled with non-compromising strips of freedom.

"Silicon Valley lobbyists are disingenuously calling for light 'regulation' of facial recognition so they can continue to profit by rapidly spreading this surveillance dragnet," according to Fight for the Future. "They're trying to avoid the real debate: whether technology this dangerous should even exist."

Evan Greer, deputy director of the group, says it doesn't that the "profound threat" to all of humanity that facial recognition poses does not justify its existence.

"We don't need to regulate it," she said. "We need to ban it entirely."

The campaign comes amid a wave of fresh headlines, all pointing to the growing Big Government outcomes of Big Technology.

Or, as Red State put it in a late June piece: "Big Government and Big Tech Are Partnering To Track Us Everywhere."

It is indeed a brave new world.

And much as Fight for the Future has a point that facial recognition is likely leading America down a path of civil rights' nightmare and Big Gov Eyes In The Skies fact is: Congress won't ban the technology.

Why not?

"Big tech has spent $582M lobbying Congress," Fox Business reported in May.

That's a drop in the bucket of the money to be made.

So long as Big Money is involved, Big Tech not to mention Big Government is here to stay.

Popri dosahoch finančnej krízy niekde v rokoch 2010 a 2011 museli banky začať čeliť ešte jednej kľúčovej zmene – digitalizácii klientov a nástupu online gigantov.

Aké výhody to prinieslo verejnosti a prečo je odrazu po dizajnéroch dopyt v IT, opisuje člen predstavenstva rakúskej Erste BankV čom vidíte radikálnu zmenu správania klientov?Klienti si zvykli na rôzne digitálne služby, ktoré neboli spojené s bankami. Začali používať Facebook, dramaticky rástol počet používateľov Amazonu. Vidím to sám na sebe. Odkedy som si stiahol do mobilu appku Amazonu, všetko ide extrémne ľahko. Na jeden klik nakupujete. Aj moje výdavky cez Amazon dramaticky vzrástli.Čo z toho vyplynulo pre banky?Bolo úplne jasné, že musíme zmeniť spôsob kontaktu s klientmi. Predtým to nebolo vždy úplne jednoduché. Prísť do pobočky, samotné úkony zaberali dosť času a boli sme na míle vzdialení od nejakého ľahkého prístupu. My sme oproti niektorým konkurentom získali výhodu, pretože sme začali relatívne skoro.Myslíte založenie laboratória vašej banky Erste Hub?Áno, aktuálne oslavujeme piate výročie jeho založenia. Cieľ bolo vybudovať malú entitu mimo banky. Bolo nevyhnutné, aby mali určitú mieru slobody – v myslení, vývoji.

Peter BosekZdroj: Erste GroupAle v podstate je to súčasť banky.Áno, ale prijímame tam iných ľudí, nie bankárov. IT vývojárov, dizajnérov a veríme, že sa nikdy nestanú bankármi. Pretože z pohľadu myslenia som názoru, že ak by sme to robili my z banky, trvalo by to večnosť. Ak dlho robíte v banke, máte už veľmi štruktúrované myslenie. Po piatich, desiatich rokoch strácate pohľad zvonku. Ale priznávam, nie je jednoduché zladiť bankovú kultúru s tou v Hube. Spočiatku sa ľudia z banky trochu sťažovali – prečo tí z Hubu majú toľko voľnosti? My musíme celý deň pracovať a oni sa zabávajú, len rozprávajú. Chvíľu mi trvalo, kým som tie dve kultúry skĺbil.Klienti sú zvyknutí na digitálne služby ako Google či Amazon, banky musia poskytnúť podobnú skúsenosť Čo znamená pohľad zvonku?Veci sa predtým robili najmä zvnútra navonok. Produkty sa vtesnávali do bilancií, prispôsobovali úrokovým potrebám banky. To chceme prekonať a snažíme sa vcítiť do kože klientov.Ako je to s inováciami? Všetko sa už vynašlo a treba len nájsť spôsob, ako to dostať do mobilov a ku klientom?Nie som si istý, či už je všetko na trhu. Ale súhlasím s vami v tom, že okolo nás je kopa technológií. Ale aj technológia je určitou komoditou a otázkou ostáva, ako ju použiť. Napríklad to môžeme prehnať. V súčasnosti máme povedzme 500 spôsobov platieb. Môžete použiť rôzne zariadenia, telefón, dokonca ho ani nemusíte aktivovať. Našou úlohou je nájsť spôsob, ktorý je pre klienta jednoduchý na manažovanie. Čo neznamená nevyhnutne zaviesť všetko, čo je dostupné.Kde je hranica medzi tým, zavádzať novinky, ale neprehnať to?Optimálna miera inovácií? Stále je cieľom pridávať užitočné inovácie, ktoré klientom šetria čas a peniaze, a nie ukazovať sa, že sme schopní si poradiť s akoukoľvek technológiou.V Hube pracujú popri IT špecialistoch dizajnéri a „brand“ špecialisti. Čo je ich úlohou?Prišli sme s novou online platformou George. Ale hľadáme aj nové prístupy v komunikácii a marketingu. Ak sa rozpamätáte na viacero bankových reklám spred niekoľkých rokov, vždy to boli banky, ktoré hovorili verejnosti o sebe. Sme najlepší v tom alebo v tom. Teraz došlo k veľmi dôležitej zmene, že banky prichádzajú s tým, ako môžu pomôcť.Akú veľkú úlohu majú dizajnéri pri inováciách?Relatívne veľkú. Pretože na konci dňa je to o zákazníkovom pocite. Netýka sa to len digitálneho bankovníctva, ale obzvlášť v ňom ide o procesy. V pobočkách stále musíte vypĺňať množstvo formulárov, kým sa dopracujete k akémukoľvek riešeniu. V digitálnej oblasti sa však snažíme konkurovať takzvaným big tech firmám. Aj keď sa nikdy nimi nestaneme, chceme im konkurovať. A to je absolútne vecou dizajnu. Nejde len o to, ako napríklad George, naše nové elektronické bankovníctvo vyzerá či koľko vecí si v ňom môžete nastaviť podľa seba. Ale hlavne o to, na koľko klikov si napríklad otvoríte účet.V týchto dňoch beží kampaň na vašu novú digitálnu platformu. Prečo George? Keď som si to hodila do prehliadača, každá tretia fotografia bola o potomkovi britského následníka trónu.Na to sú dve odpovede. Oficiálna, že George bolo meno prvého autopilota v lietadlách. Je v tom symbolika, že vám pomôže automaticky udržať váš finančný život. A poskytne vám k tomu všetky informácie. Neoficiálna verzia je, že na začiatku sme sedeli v zasadačke a niekto sa spýtal – ako sa celý projekt bude volať? A niekto iný povedal – George. A bolo to.Keď vašu novú platformu vidí človek prvýkrát, pripadá mu ako iné nové mobilné či online bankingy.Dúfam, že nie. Myslím, že sú tam obrovské rozdiely. Klasické online bankovníctvo je už na prvý pohľad veľmi štruktúrované, zatiaľ čo George je veľmi jednoduchý a hlavne intuitívny. A druhý veľmi dôležitý rozdiel je, že si veľmi veľa vecí môžete personalizovať. Nemá to význam len kvôli pohodliu či zábave, ale je to aj reálny bezpečnostný prvok, ktorý pomáha odhaliť phishingový útok [podvodníci sa vtedy cez kópie stránok bánk snažia získať heslá k účtom klientov, pozn. TREND]. Osobne veľmi oceňujem, ak napríklad posielam peniaze na účet svojho syna Alexandra, stačí mi napísať „a“ a už mi to ponúka jeho meno. Je to ako Google. Ten je tiež veľmi intuitívny a my sme si povedali, že by to aj u nás malo byť také isté.A funkcie?Snaží sa ponúkať takzvané one stop shop riešenie. Všetko teda vyriešite naraz a na jednom mieste. Ale stále to musí súvisieť s finančnými službami.

Peter BosekZdroj: Erste GroupČo si pod tým mám predstaviť?Dobrým príkladom je, keď si pôjdete do banky vybaviť hypotéku. Slovenská sporiteľňa napríklad už teraz má v rámci pobočiek tablety, kde si môžete vybrať zo zoznamu nehnuteľností, získate k tomu celkovú schému okolia – kde je najbližšia škôlka, obchody a podobne. K tomu vám ponúkneme nástroj na zistenie priemernej hodnoty nehnuteľností v oblasti. Sú to všetko pridané služby, ale stále súvisia s tou hypotékou. My nikdy nebudeme ponúkať autá alebo televízory. A takto je to podľa mňa správne, pretože nikdy nebudeme klientmi vnímaní ako dobrí predajcovia áut.Rozpoznávanie hlasu je pre banky zaujímavé, ale jeho využitie má regulačné obmedzenia. Napríklad v ochrane osobných údajov Ale súčasťou vašej skupiny je aj lízingová spoločnosť.Áno, je pre nás dôležité pôsobiť na tomto trhu, lebo je veľký. Ľudia sú veľmi zdatní vo vyhľadávaní a porovnávaní rôznych parametrov áut. Čo môžeme urobiť my, že im povieme, že z finančného hľadiska je pre vás výhodnejšie toto auto. Ale neočakávajú od nás, aby sme im odporučili farbu či typ auta.Čiže nevidíte budúcnosť online bankingu napríklad v obraze, že ak sa v rodine narodí ďalšie dieťa, banka ju online upozorní – potrebujete väčšie auto, máte k dispozícii na to toľko a toľko peňazí?To áno, ale ja neprídem s ponukou, ktoré auto si máte kúpiť.Čo nové teda príde v blízkej budúcnosti, povedzme o tri roky?Čo sa týka obsahu, budeme sa snažiť napĺňať potreby klientov. Druhou oblasťou bude ochraňovať riziko vás aj vašej rodiny. Cez poistenie. Napríklad, narodí sa vám dieťa a vy uvažujete, čo bude, keď... Rozumiem, že máte vtedy hlavu plnú iných vecí, ale riziková poistka na vašu ochranu je celkom dobrý nápad. A poslednou časťou je pomoc pri manažovaní vášho každodenného finančného života. Nie ovplyvňovaní, ale sprevádzaní. Každý musí platiť účty. Našou úlohou je, aby to bolo jednoduché a aby sme sa o to postarali. Väčšinou si ich nikto nekontroluje, lebo je to otravné. My teraz napríklad pracujeme v Georgeovi na tom, aby sme dokázali klientom posielať push hlásenia, ak sa v ich finančných zvykoch udeje niečo nezvyčajné. Napríklad platíte za nejakú službu pravidelne 30 eur. Ak zrazu odíde platba na 60 eur, pošleme vám hlásenie, aby ste si skontrolovali, či je to v poriadku.Akú zmenu zvykov vidíte u klientov so zjednodušovaním bankových služieb?V starom online bankingu sme mali takú aplikáciu na rýchlu kontrolu účtu – Quick check. Viem o štatistike za Českú republiku, kde priemerné použitie tejto služby mesačne bolo 35-krát. To znamená, že niekto si svoj zostatok pozeral aj 50- či 60-krát týždenne. Teda sa o svoj účet zaujímal viac, ako denne hovoril so svojím manželom, manželkou.Dávnejšie sa hovorilo o prepojení vašich služieb so železnicami. Ako to pokročilo?Rokujeme s rakúskymi železnicami, či by boli ochotní pripojiť sa do Georgea. Aby sa dali kúpiť lístky na pár klikov. Ale nebudeme ponúkať napríklad akcie typu teraz sú lacnejšie lístky do Salzburgu. Toto je presne o tom, vedieť si stanoviť hranicu, čo už ako banka nebudeme ponúkať. Je to len vaše rozhodnutie, či chcete ísť do Salzburgu. Ale ak sa rozhodnete, my vám uľahčíme kúpu lístka.Na čom ešte banky pracujú?Najbližšou veľkou výzvou bude rozpoznávanie hlasu. Alexa od Amazonu či iPhonová Siri. Ale musíme sa pozrieť aj na nároky regulátorov. Bolo by veľmi jednoduché dať naše funkcie do Alexy. A pre vás sa spýtať Alexy napríklad na zostatok účtu. No z pohľadu regulátorov je to relatívne komplikované.Prečo?Napríklad v prípade Alexy sú servery alokované v USA. Je tam teda veľa pravidiel z pohľadu ochrany dát. Ale na druhej strane, aj samotná spoľahlivosť rozpoznávania hlasu má limity.Napríklad?Malé dieťa si napríklad objednalo množstvo vecí cez Alexu. Pretože rozpoznávanie hlasu nefunguje na 100 percent. Ale aj napríklad reklama bežiaca v televízii. K Alexe sa prihlásite, keď poviete „Alexa“. Systém sa vtedy spustí, no ak súčasne beží v miestnosti reklama, kde zároveň niečo ponúkajú na objednanie, stalo sa, že aj keď ste to kúpiť nechceli, kúpili ste to. Čiže ešte nejaký čas to potrvá, kým sa to úplne vyvinie. Ale potom bude veľmi jednoduché komunikovať aj s bankou. Budete sedieť v aute a nebudete počúvať hudbu, ale vybavíte si svoje finančné potreby. Pritom sa stále budete koncentrovať na dopravu, pretože budete len rozprávať. To by bolo príjemné.Od tohto roka musíte na základe smernice o platobných systémoch otvoriť prístup do IT systémov aj tretím stranám, ktoré získajú po súhlase klienta možnosť namiesto vás realizovať platby. Čo to znamená pre vás a trh?Je to veľmi zaujímavá situácia a aj preto sa snažíme ostať pre klientov významným partnerom. Oblasť platieb sa otvorí pre množstvo konkurentov. V minulosti sa platby spájali absolútne len s bankami. PayPal napríklad vyvinuli len pred dekádou. Ak sa pozriete na trh fintechov v Európe, okolo 60 percent investícií smerovalo práve do platobných systémov. Každý vedel, že prichádza táto zmena od regulátora, a je veľmi zaujímavé získať údaje o vašom bankovom účte. Google už teraz mal veľmi dobrý prehľad o informáciách, ktoré hľadáte. Ale nevedel normálne, kam odchádzajú vaše peniaze. No spolu s Facebookom vybudovali ekosystém, kde môžu tieto informácie speňažiť. Ak sa pozriete na trhové pokrytie Googlu, Facebooku a bánk, je to obrovský rozdiel. A rozdiel je aj v tom, že banka nikdy nepredá informácie o vás. Ja ich môžem zbierať, aby som vám potom vyhodnotil finančnú situáciu. Pomohol vám, ak sa rozhodnete niečo urobiť. Ale nemôžem ich predať žiadnej inej spoločnosti. A verím, že toto bude pre nás nakoniec výhoda. Pretože ochota sprístupniť informácie o sebe sa veľmi líši. Kontinentálna Európa bola vždy konzervatívnejšia v zdieľaní informácií ako napríklad USA či Spojené kráľovstvo. K tomu rôzne data leaks, odcudzenie dát ako nedávno Uber – uniklo 57 miliónov kontaktných informácií o klientoch. Yahoo – niekto prenikol k 450 miliónom e-mailových adries. Nikto nechce, aby sa hocikto dostal k jeho kontaktným údajom.Ale aj oni majú niekoľkoúrovňovú bezpečnosť, nie sú v tomto porovnateľné s bankami?Vidím tam rozdiely. Napríklad čo sa týka technológií, vždy sme trochu pozadu práve pre bezpečnostné pravidlá. Je to podobné ako v leteckom priemysle. iPhony majú možno viac technológií ako airbusy. To je realita. Pretože lietadlám nie je dovolené zaviesť akúkoľvek novú technológiu okamžite. Nikto by nechcel cestovať lietadlom, ktoré ešte len skúša novú technológiu. To isté platí o bankách. Preto si myslím, že bezpečnostná úroveň bánk a online gigantov je iná.

Peter Bosek (49)

Peter BosekZdroj: Erste Group vyštudoval právnickú fakultu na Viedenskej univerzite, niekoľko rokov na nej zároveň právo prednášal. Od roku 1996 pôsobí v bankovej skupine Erste, začínal v Erste österreichische Sparkasse. V roku 2007 sa stal členom predstavenstva Erste Bank, od roku 2015 je členom predstavenstva celej Erste Group a zároveň nastúpil na novú pozíciu šéfa pre retail. Je tiež členom dozornej rady majetkovo prepojenej poisťovne Wiener Städtische.

Ale súhlasím s vami v tom, že okolo nás je kopa technológií. Ale aj technológia je určitou komoditou a otázkou ostáva, ako ju použiť. Napríklad to môžeme prehnať. V súčasnosti máme povedzme 500 spôsobov platieb. Môžete použiť rôzne zariadenia, telefón, dokonca ho ani nemusíte aktivovať. Našou úlohou je nájsť spôsob, ktorý je pre klienta jednoduchý na manažovanie. Čo neznamená nevyhnutne zaviesť všetko, čo je dostupné.

* Kde je hranica medzi tým, zavádzať novinky, ale neprehnať to?

Optimálna miera inovácií? Stále je cieľom pridávať užitočné inovácie, ktoré klientom šetria čas a peniaze, a nie ukazovať sa, že sme schopní si poradiť s akoukoľvek technológiou.

* V Hube pracujú popri IT špecialistoch dizajnéri a „brand“ špecialisti. Čo je ich úlohou?

Prišli sme s novou online platformou George. Ale hľadáme aj nové prístupy v komunikácii a marketingu. Ak sa rozpamätáte na viacero bankových reklám spred niekoľkých rokov, vždy to boli banky, ktoré hovorili verejnosti o sebe. Sme najlepší v tom alebo v tom. Teraz došlo k veľmi dôležitej zmene, že banky prichádzajú s tým, ako môžu pomôcť.

* Akú veľkú úlohu majú dizajnéri pri inováciách?

Relatívne veľkú. Pretože na konci dňa je to o zákazníkovom pocite. Netýka sa to len digitálneho bankovníctva, ale obzvlášť v ňom ide o procesy. V pobočkách stále musíte vypĺňať množstvo formulárov, kým sa dopracujete k akémukoľvek riešeniu. V digitálnej oblasti sa však snažíme konkurovať takzvaným big tech firmám. Aj keď sa nikdy nimi nestaneme, chceme im konkurovať. A to je absolútne vecou dizajnu. Nejde len o to, ako napríklad George, naše nové elektronické bankovníctvo vyzerá či koľko vecí si v ňom môžete nastaviť podľa seba. Ale hlavne o to, na koľko klikov si napríklad otvoríte účet.

* V týchto dňoch beží kampaň na vašu novú digitálnu platformu. Prečo George? Keď som si to hodila do prehliadača, každá tretia fotografia bola o potomkovi britského následníka trónu.

Na to sú dve odpovede. Oficiálna, že George bolo meno prvého autopilota v lietadlách. Je v tom symbolika, že vám pomôže automaticky udržať váš finančný život. A poskytne vám k tomu všetky informácie. Neoficiálna verzia je, že na začiatku sme sedeli v zasadačke a niekto sa spýtal – ako sa celý projekt bude volať? A niekto iný povedal – George. A bolo to.

* Keď vašu novú platformu vidí človek prvýkrát, pripadá mu ako iné nové mobilné či online bankingy.

Dúfam, že nie. Myslím, že sú tam obrovské rozdiely. Klasické online bankovníctvo je už na prvý pohľad veľmi štruktúrované, zatiaľ čo George je veľmi jednoduchý a hlavne intuitívny. A druhý veľmi dôležitý rozdiel je, že si veľmi veľa vecí môžete personalizovať. Nemá to význam len kvôli pohodliu či zábave, ale je to aj reálny bezpečnostný prvok, ktorý pomáha odhaliť phishingový útok [podvodníci sa vtedy cez kópie stránok bánk snažia získať heslá k účtom klientov, pozn. TREND]. Osobne veľmi oceňujem, ak napríklad posielam peniaze na účet svojho syna Alexandra, stačí mi napísať „a“ a už mi to ponúka jeho meno. Je to ako Google. Ten je tiež veľmi intuitívny a my sme si povedali, že by to aj u nás malo byť také isté.

* A funkcie?

Snaží sa ponúkať takzvané one stop shop riešenie. Všetko teda vyriešite naraz a na jednom mieste. Ale stále to musí súvisieť s finančnými službami.

* Čo si pod tým mám predstaviť?

Dobrým príkladom je, keď si pôjdete do banky vybaviť hypotéku. Slovenská sporiteľňa napríklad už teraz má v rámci pobočiek tablety, kde si môžete vybrať zo zoznamu nehnuteľností, získate k tomu celkovú schému okolia – kde je najbližšia škôlka, obchody a podobne. K tomu vám ponúkneme nástroj na zistenie priemernej hodnoty nehnuteľností v oblasti. Sú to všetko pridané služby, ale stále súvisia s tou hypotékou. My nikdy nebudeme ponúkať autá alebo televízory. A takto je to podľa mňa správne, pretože nikdy nebudeme klientmi vnímaní ako dobrí predajcovia áut.

* Ale súčasťou vašej skupiny je aj lízingová spoločnosť.

Áno, je pre nás dôležité pôsobiť na tomto trhu, lebo je veľký. Ľudia sú veľmi zdatní vo vyhľadávaní a porovnávaní rôznych parametrov áut. Čo môžeme urobiť my, že im povieme, že z finančného hľadiska je pre vás výhodnejšie toto auto. Ale neočakávajú od nás, aby sme im odporučili farbu či typ auta.

* Čiže nevidíte budúcnosť online bankingu napríklad v obraze, že ak sa v rodine narodí ďalšie dieťa, banka ju online upozorní – potrebujete väčšie auto, máte k dispozícii na to toľko a toľko peňazí?

To áno, ale ja neprídem s ponukou, ktoré auto si máte kúpiť.

* Čo nové teda príde v blízkej budúcnosti, povedzme o tri roky?

Čo sa týka obsahu, budeme sa snažiť napĺňať potreby klientov. Druhou oblasťou bude ochraňovať riziko vás aj vašej rodiny. Cez poistenie. Napríklad, narodí sa vám dieťa a vy uvažujete, čo bude, keď... Rozumiem, že máte vtedy hlavu plnú iných vecí, ale riziková poistka na vašu ochranu je celkom dobrý nápad. A poslednou časťou je pomoc pri manažovaní vášho každodenného finančného života. Nie ovplyvňovaní, ale sprevádzaní. Každý musí platiť účty. Našou úlohou je, aby to bolo jednoduché a aby sme sa o to postarali. Väčšinou si ich nikto nekontroluje, lebo je to otravné. My teraz napríklad pracujeme v Georgeovi na tom, aby sme dokázali klientom posielať push hlásenia, ak sa v ich finančných zvykoch udeje niečo nezvyčajné. Napríklad platíte za nejakú službu pravidelne 30 eur. Ak zrazu odíde platba na 60 eur, pošleme vám hlásenie, aby ste si skontrolovali, či je to v poriadku.

* Akú zmenu zvykov vidíte u klientov so zjednodušovaním bankových služieb?

V starom online bankingu sme mali takú aplikáciu na rýchlu kontrolu účtu – Quick check. Viem o štatistike za Českú republiku, kde priemerné použitie tejto služby mesačne bolo 35-krát. To znamená, že niekto si svoj zostatok pozeral aj 50- či 60-krát týždenne. Teda sa o svoj účet zaujímal viac, ako denne hovoril so svojím manželom, manželkou.

* Dávnejšie sa hovorilo o prepojení vašich služieb so železnicami. Ako to pokročilo?

Rokujeme s rakúskymi železnicami, či by boli ochotní pripojiť sa do Georgea. Aby sa dali kúpiť lístky na pár klikov. Ale nebudeme ponúkať napríklad akcie typu teraz sú lacnejšie lístky do Salzburgu. Toto je presne o tom, vedieť si stanoviť hranicu, čo už ako banka nebudeme ponúkať. Je to len vaše rozhodnutie, či chcete ísť do Salzburgu. Ale ak sa rozhodnete, my vám uľahčíme kúpu lístka.

* Na čom ešte banky pracujú?

Najbližšou veľkou výzvou bude rozpoznávanie hlasu. Alexa od Amazonu či iPhonová Siri. Ale musíme sa pozrieť aj na nároky regulátorov. Bolo by veľmi jednoduché dať naše funkcie do Alexy. A pre vás sa spýtať Alexy napríklad na zostatok účtu. No z pohľadu regulátorov je to relatívne komplikované.

* Prečo?

Napríklad v prípade Alexy sú servery alokované v USA. Je tam teda veľa pravidiel z pohľadu ochrany dát. Ale na druhej strane, aj samotná spoľahlivosť rozpoznávania hlasu má limity.

* Napríklad?

Malé dieťa si napríklad objednalo množstvo vecí cez Alexu. Pretože rozpoznávanie hlasu nefunguje na 100 percent. Ale aj napríklad reklama bežiaca v televízii. K Alexe sa prihlásite, keď poviete „Alexa“. Systém sa vtedy spustí, no ak súčasne beží v miestnosti reklama, kde zároveň niečo ponúkajú na objednanie, stalo sa, že aj keď ste to kúpiť nechceli, kúpili ste to. Čiže ešte nejaký čas to potrvá, kým sa to úplne vyvinie. Ale potom bude veľmi jednoduché komunikovať aj s bankou. Budete sedieť v aute a nebudete počúvať hudbu, ale vybavíte si svoje finančné potreby. Pritom sa stále budete koncentrovať na dopravu, pretože budete len rozprávať. To by bolo príjemné.

* Od tohto roka musíte na základe smernice o platobných systémoch otvoriť prístup do IT systémov aj tretím stranám, ktoré získajú po súhlase klienta možnosť namiesto vás realizovať platby. Čo to znamená pre vás a trh?

Je to veľmi zaujímavá situácia a aj preto sa snažíme ostať pre klientov významným partnerom. Oblasť platieb sa otvorí pre množstvo konkurentov. V minulosti sa platby spájali absolútne len s bankami. PayPal napríklad vyvinuli len pred dekádou. Ak sa pozriete na trh fintechov v Európe, okolo 60 percent investícií smerovalo práve do platobných systémov. Každý vedel, že prichádza táto zmena od regulátora, a je veľmi zaujímavé získať údaje o vašom bankovom účte. Google už teraz mal veľmi dobrý prehľad o informáciách, ktoré hľadáte. Ale nevedel normálne, kam odchádzajú vaše peniaze. No spolu s Facebookom vybudovali ekosystém, kde môžu tieto informácie speňažiť. Ak sa pozriete na trhové pokrytie Googlu, Facebooku a bánk, je to obrovský rozdiel. A rozdiel je aj v tom, že banka nikdy nepredá informácie o vás. Ja ich môžem zbierať, aby som vám potom vyhodnotil finančnú situáciu. Pomohol vám, ak sa rozhodnete niečo urobiť. Ale nemôžem ich predať žiadnej inej spoločnosti. A verím, že toto bude pre nás nakoniec výhoda. Pretože ochota sprístupniť informácie o sebe sa veľmi líši. Kontinentálna Európa bola vždy konzervatívnejšia v zdieľaní informácií ako napríklad USA či Spojené kráľovstvo. K tomu rôzne data leaks, odcudzenie dát ako nedávno Uber – uniklo 57 miliónov kontaktných informácií o klientoch. Yahoo – niekto prenikol k 450 miliónom e-mailových adries. Nikto nechce, aby sa hocikto dostal k jeho kontaktným údajom.

* Ale aj oni majú niekoľkoúrovňovú bezpečnosť, nie sú v tomto porovnateľné s bankami?

Vidím tam rozdiely. Napríklad čo sa týka technológií, vždy sme trochu pozadu práve pre bezpečnostné pravidlá. Je to podobné ako v leteckom priemysle. iPhony majú možno viac technológií ako airbusy. To je realita. Pretože lietadlám nie je dovolené zaviesť akúkoľvek novú technológiu okamžite. Nikto by nechcel cestovať lietadlom, ktoré ešte len skúša novú technológiu. To isté platí o bankách. Preto si myslím, že bezpečnostná úroveň bánk a online gigantov je iná.

***

Klienti sú zvyknutí na digitálne služby ako Google či Amazon, banky musia poskytnúť podobnú skúsenosť

Peter Bosek (49) vyštudoval právnickú fakultu na Viedenskej univerzite, niekoľko rokov na nej zároveň právo prednášal. Od roku 1996 pôsobí v bankovej skupine Erste, začínal v Erste österreichische Sparkasse. V roku 2007 sa stal členom predstavenstva Erste Bank, od roku 2015 je členom predstavenstva celej Erste Group a zároveň nastúpil na novú pozíciu šéfa pre retail. Je tiež členom dozornej rady majetkovo prepojenej poisťovne Wiener Städtische.
