A druhý veľmi dôležitý rozdiel je, že si veľmi veľa vecí môžete personalizovať. Nemá to význam len kvôli pohodliu či zábave, ale je to aj reálny bezpečnostný prvok, ktorý pomáha odhaliť phishingový útok [podvodníci sa vtedy cez kópie stránok bánk snažia získať heslá k účtom klientov, pozn. TREND]. Osobne veľmi oceňujem, ak napríklad posielam peniaze na účet svojho syna Alexandra, stačí mi napísať „a“ a už mi to ponúka jeho meno. Je to ako Google. Ten je tiež veľmi intuitívny a my sme si povedali, že by to aj u nás malo byť také isté.

* A funkcie?

Snaží sa ponúkať takzvané one stop shop riešenie. Všetko teda vyriešite naraz a na jednom mieste. Ale stále to musí súvisieť s finančnými službami.

* Čo si pod tým mám predstaviť?

Dobrým príkladom je, keď si pôjdete do banky vybaviť hypotéku. Slovenská sporiteľňa napríklad už teraz má v rámci pobočiek tablety, kde si môžete vybrať zo zoznamu nehnuteľností, získate k tomu celkovú schému okolia – kde je najbližšia škôlka, obchody a podobne. K tomu vám ponúkneme nástroj na zistenie priemernej hodnoty nehnuteľností v oblasti. Sú to všetko pridané služby, ale stále súvisia s tou hypotékou. My nikdy nebudeme ponúkať autá alebo televízory. A takto je to podľa mňa správne, pretože nikdy nebudeme klientmi vnímaní ako dobrí predajcovia áut.

* Ale súčasťou vašej skupiny je aj lízingová spoločnosť.

Áno, je pre nás dôležité pôsobiť na tomto trhu, lebo je veľký. Ľudia sú veľmi zdatní vo vyhľadávaní a porovnávaní rôznych parametrov áut. Čo môžeme urobiť my, že im povieme, že z finančného hľadiska je pre vás výhodnejšie toto auto. Ale neočakávajú od nás, aby sme im odporučili farbu či typ auta.

* Čiže nevidíte budúcnosť online bankingu napríklad v obraze, že ak sa v rodine narodí ďalšie dieťa, banka ju online upozorní – potrebujete väčšie auto, máte k dispozícii na to toľko a toľko peňazí?

To áno, ale ja neprídem s ponukou, ktoré auto si máte kúpiť.

* Čo nové teda príde v blízkej budúcnosti, povedzme o tri roky?

Čo sa týka obsahu, budeme sa snažiť napĺňať potreby klientov. Druhou oblasťou bude ochraňovať riziko vás aj vašej rodiny. Cez poistenie. Napríklad, narodí sa vám dieťa a vy uvažujete, čo bude, keď... Rozumiem, že máte vtedy hlavu plnú iných vecí, ale riziková poistka na vašu ochranu je celkom dobrý nápad. A poslednou časťou je pomoc pri manažovaní vášho každodenného finančného života. Nie ovplyvňovaní, ale sprevádzaní. Každý musí platiť účty. Našou úlohou je, aby to bolo jednoduché a aby sme sa o to postarali. Väčšinou si ich nikto nekontroluje, lebo je to otravné. My teraz napríklad pracujeme v Georgeovi na tom, aby sme dokázali klientom posielať push hlásenia, ak sa v ich finančných zvykoch udeje niečo nezvyčajné. Napríklad platíte za nejakú službu pravidelne 30 eur. Ak zrazu odíde platba na 60 eur, pošleme vám hlásenie, aby ste si skontrolovali, či je to v poriadku.

* Akú zmenu zvykov vidíte u klientov so zjednodušovaním bankových služieb?

V starom online bankingu sme mali takú aplikáciu na rýchlu kontrolu účtu – Quick check. Viem o štatistike za Českú republiku, kde priemerné použitie tejto služby mesačne bolo 35-krát. To znamená, že niekto si svoj zostatok pozeral aj 50- či 60-krát týždenne. Teda sa o svoj účet zaujímal viac, ako denne hovoril so svojím manželom, manželkou.

* Dávnejšie sa hovorilo o prepojení vašich služieb so železnicami. Ako to pokročilo?

Rokujeme s rakúskymi železnicami, či by boli ochotní pripojiť sa do Georgea. Aby sa dali kúpiť lístky na pár klikov. Ale nebudeme ponúkať napríklad akcie typu teraz sú lacnejšie lístky do Salzburgu. Toto je presne o tom, vedieť si stanoviť hranicu, čo už ako banka nebudeme ponúkať. Je to len vaše rozhodnutie, či chcete ísť do Salzburgu. Ale ak sa rozhodnete, my vám uľahčíme kúpu lístka.

* Na čom ešte banky pracujú?

Najbližšou veľkou výzvou bude rozpoznávanie hlasu. Alexa od Amazonu či iPhonová Siri. Ale musíme sa pozrieť aj na nároky regulátorov. Bolo by veľmi jednoduché dať naše funkcie do Alexy. A pre vás sa spýtať Alexy napríklad na zostatok účtu. No z pohľadu regulátorov je to relatívne komplikované.

* Prečo?

Napríklad v prípade Alexy sú servery alokované v USA. Je tam teda veľa pravidiel z pohľadu ochrany dát. Ale na druhej strane, aj samotná spoľahlivosť rozpoznávania hlasu má limity.

* Napríklad?

Malé dieťa si napríklad objednalo množstvo vecí cez Alexu. Pretože rozpoznávanie hlasu nefunguje na 100 percent. Ale aj napríklad reklama bežiaca v televízii. K Alexe sa prihlásite, keď poviete „Alexa“. Systém sa vtedy spustí, no ak súčasne beží v miestnosti reklama, kde zároveň niečo ponúkajú na objednanie, stalo sa, že aj keď ste to kúpiť nechceli, kúpili ste to. Čiže ešte nejaký čas to potrvá, kým sa to úplne vyvinie. Ale potom bude veľmi jednoduché komunikovať aj s bankou. Budete sedieť v aute a nebudete počúvať hudbu, ale vybavíte si svoje finančné potreby. Pritom sa stále budete koncentrovať na dopravu, pretože budete len rozprávať. To by bolo príjemné.

* Od tohto roka musíte na základe smernice o platobných systémoch otvoriť prístup do IT systémov aj tretím stranám, ktoré získajú po súhlase klienta možnosť namiesto vás realizovať platby. Čo to znamená pre vás a trh?

Je to veľmi zaujímavá situácia a aj preto sa snažíme ostať pre klientov významným partnerom. Oblasť platieb sa otvorí pre množstvo konkurentov. V minulosti sa platby spájali absolútne len s bankami. PayPal napríklad vyvinuli len pred dekádou. Ak sa pozriete na trh fintechov v Európe, okolo 60 percent investícií smerovalo práve do platobných systémov. Každý vedel, že prichádza táto zmena od regulátora, a je veľmi zaujímavé získať údaje o vašom bankovom účte. Google už teraz mal veľmi dobrý prehľad o informáciách, ktoré hľadáte. Ale nevedel normálne, kam odchádzajú vaše peniaze. No spolu s Facebookom vybudovali ekosystém, kde môžu tieto informácie speňažiť. Ak sa pozriete na trhové pokrytie Googlu, Facebooku a bánk, je to obrovský rozdiel. A rozdiel je aj v tom, že banka nikdy nepredá informácie o vás. Ja ich môžem zbierať, aby som vám potom vyhodnotil finančnú situáciu. Pomohol vám, ak sa rozhodnete niečo urobiť. Ale nemôžem ich predať žiadnej inej spoločnosti. A verím, že toto bude pre nás nakoniec výhoda. Pretože ochota sprístupniť informácie o sebe sa veľmi líši. Kontinentálna Európa bola vždy konzervatívnejšia v zdieľaní informácií ako napríklad USA či Spojené kráľovstvo. K tomu rôzne data leaks, odcudzenie dát ako nedávno Uber – uniklo 57 miliónov kontaktných informácií o klientoch. Yahoo – niekto prenikol k 450 miliónom e-mailových adries. Nikto nechce, aby sa hocikto dostal k jeho kontaktným údajom.

* Ale aj oni majú niekoľkoúrovňovú bezpečnosť, nie sú v tomto porovnateľné s bankami?

Vidím tam rozdiely. Napríklad čo sa týka technológií, vždy sme trochu pozadu práve pre bezpečnostné pravidlá. Je to podobné ako v leteckom priemysle. iPhony majú možno viac technológií ako airbusy. To je realita. Pretože lietadlám nie je dovolené zaviesť akúkoľvek novú technológiu okamžite. Nikto by nechcel cestovať lietadlom, ktoré ešte len skúša novú technológiu. To isté platí o bankách. Preto si myslím, že bezpečnostná úroveň bánk a online gigantov je iná.

***

Klienti sú zvyknutí na digitálne služby ako Google či Amazon, banky musia poskytnúť podobnú skúsenosť

Peter Bosek (49) vyštudoval právnickú fakultu na Viedenskej univerzite, niekoľko rokov na nej zároveň právo prednášal. Od roku 1996 pôsobí v bankovej skupine Erste, začínal v Erste österreichische Sparkasse. V roku 2007 sa stal členom predstavenstva Erste Bank, od roku 2015 je členom predstavenstva celej Erste Group a zároveň nastúpil na novú pozíciu šéfa pre retail. Je tiež členom dozornej rady majetkovo prepojenej poisťovne Wiener Städtische.

Ako nájsť optimálnu mieru technologických noviniek, aby ste to u klienta neprešvihli, rozpráva Peter Bosek z Erste Group, rakúskej matky Slovenskej sporiteľne

Popri dosahoch finančnej krízy niekde v rokoch 2010 a 2011 museli banky začať čeliť ešte jednej kľúčovej zmene – digitalizácii klientov a nástupu online gigantov. Aké výhody to prinieslo verejnosti a prečo je odrazu po dizajnéroch dopyt v IT, opisuje člen predstavenstva rakúskej Erste Bank

* V čom vidíte radikálnu zmenu správania klientov?

Klienti si zvykli na rôzne digitálne služby, ktoré neboli spojené s bankami. Začali používať Facebook, dramaticky rástol počet používateľov Amazonu. Vidím to sám na sebe. Odkedy som si stiahol do mobilu appku Amazonu, všetko ide extrémne ľahko. Na jeden klik nakupujete. Aj moje výdavky cez Amazon dramaticky vzrástli.

* Čo z toho vyplynulo pre banky?

Bolo úplne jasné, že musíme zmeniť spôsob kontaktu s klientmi. Predtým to nebolo vždy úplne jednoduché. Prísť do pobočky, samotné úkony zaberali dosť času a boli sme na míle vzdialení od nejakého ľahkého prístupu. My sme oproti niektorým konkurentom získali výhodu, pretože sme začali relatívne skoro.

* Myslíte založenie laboratória vašej banky Erste Hub?

Áno, aktuálne oslavujeme piate výročie jeho založenia. Cieľ bolo vybudovať malú entitu mimo banky. Bolo nevyhnutné, aby mali určitú mieru slobody – v myslení, vývoji.

* Ale v podstate je to súčasť banky.

Áno, ale prijímame tam iných ľudí, nie bankárov. IT vývojárov, dizajnérov a veríme, že sa nikdy nestanú bankármi. Pretože z pohľadu myslenia som názoru, že ak by sme to robili my z banky, trvalo by to večnosť. Ak dlho robíte v banke, máte už veľmi štruktúrované myslenie. Po piatich, desiatich rokoch strácate pohľad zvonku. Ale priznávam, nie je jednoduché zladiť bankovú kultúru s tou v Hube. Spočiatku sa ľudia z banky trochu sťažovali – prečo tí z Hubu majú toľko voľnosti? My musíme celý deň pracovať a oni sa zabávajú, len rozprávajú. Chvíľu mi trvalo, kým som tie dve kultúry skĺbil.

* Čo znamená pohľad zvonku?

Veci sa predtým robili najmä zvnútra navonok. Produkty sa vtesnávali do bilancií, prispôsobovali úrokovým potrebám banky. To chceme prekonať a snažíme sa vcítiť do kože klientov.

* Ako je to s inováciami? Všetko sa už vynašlo a treba len nájsť spôsob, ako to dostať do mobilov a ku klientom? Nie som si istý, či už je všetko na trhu. Ale súhlasím s vami v tom, že okolo nás je kopa technológií. Ale aj technológia je určitou komoditou a otázkou ostáva, ako ju použiť. Napríklad to môžeme prehnať. V súčasnosti máme povedzme 500 spôsobov platieb. Môžete použiť rôzne zariadenia, telefón, dokonca ho ani nemusíte aktivovať. Našou úlohou je nájsť spôsob, ktorý je pre klienta jednoduchý na manažovanie. Čo neznamená nevyhnutne zaviesť všetko, čo je dostupné.

* Kde je hranica medzi tým, zavádzať novinky, ale neprehnať to?

Optimálna miera inovácií? Stále je cieľom pridávať užitočné inovácie, ktoré klientom šetria čas a peniaze, a nie ukazovať sa, že sme schopní si poradiť s akoukoľvek technológiou.

* V Hube pracujú popri IT špecialistoch dizajnéri a „brand“ špecialisti. Čo je ich úlohou?

Prišli sme s novou online platformou George. Ale hľadáme aj nové prístupy v komunikácii a marketingu. Ak sa rozpamätáte na viacero bankových reklám spred niekoľkých rokov, vždy to boli banky, ktoré hovorili verejnosti o sebe. Sme najlepší v tom alebo v tom. Teraz došlo k veľmi dôležitej zmene, že banky prichádzajú s tým, ako môžu pomôcť.

Relatívne veľkú. Pretože na konci dňa je to o zákazníkovom pocite. Netýka sa to len digitálneho bankovníctva, ale obzvlášť v ňom ide o procesy. V pobočkách stále musíte vypĺňať množstvo formulárov, kým sa dopracujete k akémukoľvek riešeniu. V digitálnej oblasti sa však snažíme konkurovať takzvaným big tech firmám. Aj keď sa nikdy nimi nestaneme, chceme im konkurovať. A to je absolútne vecou dizajnu. Nejde len o to, ako napríklad George, naše nové elektronické bankovníctvo vyzerá či koľko vecí si v ňom môžete nastaviť podľa seba. Ale hlavne o to, na koľko klikov si napríklad otvoríte účet.

* V týchto dňoch beží kampaň na vašu novú digitálnu platformu. Prečo George? Keď som si to hodila do prehliadača, každá tretia fotografia bola o potomkovi britského následníka trónu.

Na to sú dve odpovede. Oficiálna, že George bolo meno prvého autopilota v lietadlách. Je v tom symbolika, že vám pomôže automaticky udržať váš finančný život. A poskytne vám k tomu všetky informácie. Neoficiálna verzia je, že na začiatku sme sedeli v zasadačke a niekto sa spýtal – ako sa celý projekt bude volať? A niekto iný povedal – George. A bolo to.

* Čo nové teda príde v blízkej budúcnosti, povedzme o tri roky?

Čo sa týka obsahu, budeme sa snažiť napĺňať potreby klientov. Druhou oblasťou bude ochraňovať riziko vás aj vašej rodiny. Cez poistenie. Napríklad, narodí sa vám dieťa a vy uvažujete, čo bude, keď... Rozumiem, že máte vtedy hlavu plnú iných vecí, ale riziková poistka na vašu ochranu je celkom dobrý nápad. A poslednou časťou je pomoc pri manažovaní vášho každodenného finančného života. Nie ovplyvňovaní, ale sprevádzaní. Každý musí platiť účty. Našou úlohou je, aby to bolo jednoduché a aby sme sa o to postarali. Väčšinou si ich nikto nekontroluje, lebo je to otravné. My teraz napríklad pracujeme v Georgeovi na tom, aby sme dokázali klientom posielať push hlásenia, ak sa v ich finančných zvykoch udeje niečo nezvyčajné. Napríklad platíte za nejakú službu pravidelne 30 eur. Ak zrazu odíde platba na 60 eur, pošleme vám hlásenie, aby ste si skontrolovali, či je to v poriadku.

* Akú zmenu zvykov vidíte u klientov so zjednodušovaním bankových služieb?

V starom online bankingu sme mali takú aplikáciu na rýchlu kontrolu účtu – Quick check. Viem o štatistike za Českú republiku, kde priemerné použitie tejto služby mesačne bolo 35-krát. To znamená, že niekto si svoj zostatok pozeral aj 50- či 60-krát týždenne. Teda sa o svoj účet zaujímal viac, ako denne hovoril so svojím manželom, manželkou.

* Dávnejšie sa hovorilo o prepojení vašich služieb so železnicami. Ako to pokročilo?

Rokujeme s rakúskymi železnicami, či by boli ochotní pripojiť sa do Georgea. Aby sa dali kúpiť lístky na pár klikov. Ale nebudeme ponúkať napríklad akcie typu teraz sú lacnejšie lístky do Salzburgu. Toto je presne o tom, vedieť si stanoviť hranicu, čo už ako banka nebudeme ponúkať. Je to len vaše rozhodnutie, či chcete ísť do Salzburgu. Ale ak sa rozhodnete, my vám uľahčíme kúpu lístka.

* Na čom ešte banky pracujú?

Najbližšou veľkou výzvou bude rozpoznávanie hlasu. Alexa od Amazonu či iPhonová Siri. Ale musíme sa pozrieť aj na nároky regulátorov. Bolo by veľmi jednoduché dať naše funkcie do Alexy. A pre vás sa spýtať Alexy napríklad na zostatok účtu. No z pohľadu regulátorov je to relatívne komplikované.

* Prečo?

Napríklad v prípade Alexy sú servery alokované v USA. Je tam teda veľa pravidiel z pohľadu ochrany dát. Ale na druhej strane, aj samotná spoľahlivosť rozpoznávania hlasu má limity.

* Napríklad?

Malé dieťa si napríklad objednalo množstvo vecí cez Alexu. Pretože rozpoznávanie hlasu nefunguje na 100 percent. Ale aj napríklad reklama bežiaca v televízii. K Alexe sa prihlásite, keď poviete „Alexa“. Systém sa vtedy spustí, no ak súčasne beží v miestnosti reklama, kde zároveň niečo ponúkajú na objednanie, stalo sa, že aj keď ste to kúpiť nechceli, kúpili ste to. Čiže ešte nejaký čas to potrvá, kým sa to úplne vyvinie. Ale potom bude veľmi jednoduché komunikovať aj s bankou. Budete sedieť v aute a nebudete počúvať hudbu, ale vybavíte si svoje finančné potreby. Pritom sa stále budete koncentrovať na dopravu, pretože budete len rozprávať. To by bolo príjemné.

* Od tohto roka musíte na základe smernice o platobných systémoch otvoriť prístup do IT systémov aj tretím stranám, ktoré získajú po súhlase klienta možnosť namiesto vás realizovať platby. Čo to znamená pre vás a trh?

Je to veľmi zaujímavá situácia a aj preto sa snažíme ostať pre klientov významným partnerom. Oblasť platieb sa otvorí pre množstvo konkurentov. V minulosti sa platby spájali absolútne len s bankami. PayPal napríklad vyvinuli len pred dekádou. Ak sa pozriete na trh fintechov v Európe, okolo 60 percent investícií smerovalo práve do platobných systémov. Každý vedel, že prichádza táto zmena od regulátora, a je veľmi zaujímavé získať údaje o vašom bankovom účte. Google už teraz mal veľmi dobrý prehľad o informáciách, ktoré hľadáte. Ale nevedel normálne, kam odchádzajú vaše peniaze. No spolu s Facebookom vybudovali ekosystém, kde môžu tieto informácie speňažiť. Ak sa pozriete na trhové pokrytie Googlu, Facebooku a bánk, je to obrovský rozdiel. A rozdiel je aj v tom, že banka nikdy nepredá informácie o vás. Ja ich môžem zbierať, aby som vám potom vyhodnotil finančnú situáciu. Pomohol vám, ak sa rozhodnete niečo urobiť. Ale nemôžem ich predať žiadnej inej spoločnosti. A verím, že toto bude pre nás nakoniec výhoda. Pretože ochota sprístupniť informácie o sebe sa veľmi líši. Kontinentálna Európa bola vždy konzervatívnejšia v zdieľaní informácií ako napríklad USA či Spojené kráľovstvo. K tomu rôzne data leaks, odcudzenie dát ako nedávno Uber – uniklo 57 miliónov kontaktných informácií o klientoch. Yahoo – niekto prenikol k 450 miliónom e-mailových adries. Nikto nechce, aby sa hocikto dostal k jeho kontaktným údajom.

* Ale aj oni majú niekoľkoúrovňovú bezpečnosť, nie sú v tomto porovnateľné s bankami?

Vidím tam rozdiely. Napríklad čo sa týka technológií, vždy sme trochu pozadu práve pre bezpečnostné pravidlá. Je to podobné ako v leteckom priemysle. iPhony majú možno viac technológií ako airbusy. To je realita. Pretože lietadlám nie je dovolené zaviesť akúkoľvek novú technológiu okamžite. Nikto by nechcel cestovať lietadlom, ktoré ešte len skúša novú technológiu. To isté platí o bankách. Preto si myslím, že bezpečnostná úroveň bánk a online gigantov je iná.

***

Klienti sú zvyknutí na digitálne služby ako Google či Amazon, banky musia poskytnúť podobnú skúsenosť

Od roku 1996 pôsobí v bankovej skupine Erste, začínal v Erste österreichische Sparkasse. V roku 2007 sa stal členom predstavenstva Erste Bank, od roku 2015 je členom predstavenstva celej Erste Group a zároveň nastúpil na novú pozíciu šéfa pre retail. urn:contentItem:5F8F-9GP1-DXXG-620R-00000-00Bank branches can help combat digital competitors, says Ana Botin2015-02-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:16ZLexisNexisBank branches can help combat digital competitors, says Ana Botin

Old-school bank branches still hold value and hence, a significant retail presence can help offset the onslaught of the big technology groups in the banking arena, Ana Botin told The Financial Times in her first interview since taking charge of the Spain's Banco Santander.

Botín confessed that tech giants Apple, Facebook, Google and Amazon are a threat to banks. However, she stressed that banks are well equipped to ward off these competitors.

"You are not going to get married through technology. You are not going to buy a house through technology. I think that is where we are going to compete very effectively with these guys, if we can find a model that combines the personal side with the technology," said Botin.

She added, "The fact is even young people like to go to a branch at least twice a year. That means you need quite a significant retail presence, which they [the big tech groups] don't have."

Botin admitted that the big four tech companies are cash rich and have less regulation.

Highlighting that regulation can be turned into a positive Botin added, "Regulators are not just looking at our credit and market risk, they are looking at our IT and cyber risk. So we pay a big price, but we also have the advantage that you can probably trust us more than others."

Botin also emphasized digital banking as a core theme and commented, "I think of digital as a means to an end: How do I service and get more loyal customers: how do I achieve operational excellence and how do I change my culture? Those are my three building blocks and if you think about it, digital comes into it in every single one of them."

urn:contentItem:5Y1X-X8F1-JCRW-514P-00000-00Bank CEOs push back on climate proposals; another company leaves Libra2020-01-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:16ZLexisNexisBank CEOs push back on climate proposals; another company leaves LibraGeorge Yacik

Wall Street JournalBringing in innovation

Ally Financial's new Chief Information Officer Sathish Muthukrishnan "aims toupdate the company's financial toolswith more innovations made possible by artificial intelligence, with security baked into the development process. The company is using AI technologies such as Amazon.com's Alexa for voice-enabled online banking and biometrics for customers to log into the mobile banking app," the paper says.

"We have to strike a right balance between operating within a regulated bank, and bringing in innovation," Muthukrishnan told the paper. "He wants to improve the user experience in its digital platforms and personalize financial tools for customers."

UBS CEO Sergio Ermotti has lowered the bank's financial targets, making them easier to clear for himself, "and the four board members vying to replace" him. On Tuesday Ermotti, who "has been in post since 2011 and is expected to retire before the end of 2022," cut the bank's financial targets and dividend and buyback plans over the next three years.

"Beating his targets would be a nice send-off. This seemsachievable at the reduced level- and with ambitious potential successors keen to prove their skills," the paper said. "While an external candidate is always possible, investors should keep an eye on the internal race to beat the bank's targets. It won't just determine the stock performance, but will also provide interesting insight into who might lead the bank next."

Financial TimesNot their job

The heads of major international banks and financial companies "rejected suggestions that they are not doing enough to combat climate change and resisted calls that they should refuse to work with clients that are major polluters." Speaking at the World Economic Forum in Davos Tuesday, Citigroup CEO Michael Corbat "said it was not the job of banks to ensure that companies were adopting environmentally friendly business models by unilaterally cutting off finance for polluting businesses."

"I don't want to be the sharp end of the spear, meaning I don't want to have to be the one telling companies or enforcing standards in an industry or business," he said.

"Should we not raise money for a company that is a carbon company or a fossil fuel company?" Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon asked. "The answer is no, we're not going to stop doing that. There's a transition that's going on, and my view is this isgoing to be a multi-decade transitionwhere we see changes in the way people allocate capital."

Vodafone, the U.K.-based phone company, has "became the latest big tech company toabandon the controversial Libra project, inflicting a fresh blow to the Facebook-led digital currency initiative." The firm is the eighth company "to pull out of the ambitious project, which has faced intense scrutiny from global regulators and politicians over concerns it could facilitate money laundering and hurt financial stability." Vodafone said it would "instead redirect its efforts towards its own mobile money payments service, M-Pesa," the paper reports.

"We have said from the outset that Vodafone's desire is to make a genuine contribution to extending financial inclusion," a spokesperson told the paper. "We remain fully committed to that goal and feel that we can make the most contribution by focusing our efforts on M-Pesa. We will continue to monitor the development of the Libra Association and do not rule out the possibility of future co-operation."

Mark Bailie, the head of Royal Bank of Scotland's newly launched digital unit Bó, is planning to leave the bank later this year, the paper reports. Bailie "had been one of theleading internal candidatesto succeed Ross McEwan, who resigned as chief executive last year. However, he was beaten to the post by Alison Rose, who became the first woman to lead one of the U.K.'s big four high street lenders." His departure "comes less than two months after the formal launch of Bó, the digital banking project that he had worked on for the past two years."

Meanwhile, Monese, a U.K.-based startup digital bank, "is in talks to raise £100 million from investors in a deal that is expected to make it the latest British technology unicorn." The company, which provides an app-based bank checking account to consumers and businesses, "has differentiated itself from rivals by targetingpeople who struggle to access traditional banks, such as recent immigrants who do not have local credit histories." The company, which was founded in 2013, doubled the number of customers to two million in the second half of last year and is aiming to hit five million by the end of this year.

The risks to global banks have lessened somewhat due to more stringent capital rules, but "there arenew threats on the horizon. They include a surge in loans to highly indebted companies that could quickly fall into difficulty in the event of a recession and struggle to make their repayments." A session at the World Economic Forum explores the question, "With cheap money keeping fragile companies on life support, will a recession cause a reckoning in corporate debt?"

ElsewherePapa's got a brand new bag

Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon, "who spins electronic dance music under the moniker DJ D-Sol, will be featured at a Sports Illustrated partytied to the NFL's Super Bowl," Bloomberg reports.

urn:contentItem:5Y1S-X151-JCRW-552W-00000-00Bank CEOs push back on climate proposals; another company leaves Libra2020-01-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:16ZLexisNexisBank CEOs push back on climate proposals; another company leaves LibraGeorge Yacik

Wall Street JournalBringing in innovation

Ally Financial's new Chief Information Officer Sathish Muthukrishnan "aims toupdate the company's financial toolswith more innovations made possible by artificial intelligence, with security baked into the development process. The company is using AI technologies such as Amazon.com's Alexa for voice-enabled online banking and biometrics for customers to log into the mobile banking app," the paper says.

"We have to strike a right balance between operating within a regulated bank, and bringing in innovation," Muthukrishnan told the paper. "He wants to improve the user experience in its digital platforms and personalize financial tools for customers."

UBS CEO Sergio Ermotti has lowered the bank's financial targets, making them easier to clear for himself, "and the four board members vying to replace" him. On Tuesday Ermotti, who "has been in post since 2011 and is expected to retire before the end of 2022," cut the bank's financial targets and dividend and buyback plans over the next three years.

"Beating his targets would be a nice send-off. This seemsachievable at the reduced level- and with ambitious potential successors keen to prove their skills," the paper said. "While an external candidate is always possible, investors should keep an eye on the internal race to beat the bank's targets. It won't just determine the stock performance, but will also provide interesting insight into who might lead the bank next."

Financial TimesNot their job

The heads of major international banks and financial companies "rejected suggestions that they are not doing enough to combat climate change and resisted calls that they should refuse to work with clients that are major polluters." Speaking at the World Economic Forum in Davos Tuesday, Citigroup CEO Michael Corbat "said it was not the job of banks to ensure that companies were adopting environmentally friendly business models by unilaterally cutting off finance for polluting businesses."

"I don't want to be the sharp end of the spear, meaning I don't want to have to be the one telling companies or enforcing standards in an industry or business," he said.

"Should we not raise money for a company that is a carbon company or a fossil fuel company?" Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon asked. "The answer is no, we're not going to stop doing that. There's a transition that's going on, and my view is this isgoing to be a multi-decade transitionwhere we see changes in the way people allocate capital."

Vodafone, the U.K.-based phone company, has "became the latest big tech company toabandon the controversial Libra project, inflicting a fresh blow to the Facebook-led digital currency initiative." The firm is the eighth company "to pull out of the ambitious project, which has faced intense scrutiny from global regulators and politicians over concerns it could facilitate money laundering and hurt financial stability." Vodafone said it would "instead redirect its efforts towards its own mobile money payments service, M-Pesa," the paper reports.

"We have said from the outset that Vodafone's desire is to make a genuine contribution to extending financial inclusion," a spokesperson told the paper. "We remain fully committed to that goal and feel that we can make the most contribution by focusing our efforts on M-Pesa. We will continue to monitor the development of the Libra Association and do not rule out the possibility of future co-operation."

Mark Bailie, the head of Royal Bank of Scotland's newly launched digital unit Bó, is planning to leave the bank later this year, the paper reports. Bailie "had been one of theleading internal candidatesto succeed Ross McEwan, who resigned as chief executive last year. However, he was beaten to the post by Alison Rose, who became the first woman to lead one of the U.K.'s big four high street lenders." His departure "comes less than two months after the formal launch of Bó, the digital banking project that he had worked on for the past two years."

Meanwhile, Monese, a U.K.-based startup digital bank, "is in talks to raise £100 million from investors in a deal that is expected to make it the latest British technology unicorn." The company, which provides an app-based bank checking account to consumers and businesses, "has differentiated itself from rivals by targetingpeople who struggle to access traditional banks, such as recent immigrants who do not have local credit histories." The company, which was founded in 2013, doubled the number of customers to two million in the second half of last year and is aiming to hit five million by the end of this year.

The risks to global banks have lessened somewhat due to more stringent capital rules, but "there arenew threats on the horizon. They include a surge in loans to highly indebted companies that could quickly fall into difficulty in the event of a recession and struggle to make their repayments." A session at the World Economic Forum explores the question, "With cheap money keeping fragile companies on life support, will a recession cause a reckoning in corporate debt?"

ElsewherePapa's got a brand new bag

Goldman Sachs CEO David Solomon, "who spins electronic dance music under the moniker DJ D-Sol, will be featured at a Sports Illustrated partytied to the NFL's Super Bowl," Bloomberg reports.

"A bank's job is to support the communities in which it operates. It isnot to dictate outcomes.

urn:contentItem:5XD2-HWP1-DY1C-70R9-00000-00Banken müssen sich den Markt mit Big Techs teilen;LBBW hält Koexistenz für wahrscheinlich und Aufstieg von Digitalwährungen für unaufhaltsam - DZ Bank skizziert Libra-Nutzungen2019-10-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:16ZLexisNexisDIGITALE WÄHRUNGENS. 4Banken müssen sich den Markt mit Big Techs teilenLBBW hält Koexistenz für wahrscheinlich und Aufstieg von Digitalwährungen für unaufhaltsam - DZ Bank skizziert Libra-NutzungenFIR Frankfurt

Börsen-Zeitung, 31.10.2019

fir Frankfurt - Der Aufstieg von Techfirmen im Finanzwesen ist nach Ansicht von LBBW Research unaufhaltsam und wird wahrscheinlich zu einer Aufteilung des Marktes zwischen sogenannten Big Techs und klassischen Banken führen. In einer Studie, welche die Auswirkungen digitaler Währungen wie der hochumstrittenen, von Facebook geplanten Libra auf das Bankensystem thematisiert, halten die Autoren das vom Internationalen Währungsfonds (IWF) skizzierte Szenario der Koexistenz am ehesten für plausibel.

Dass Anbieter elektronischen Geldes im direkten Wettbewerb um Zahlungssysteme und Einlagen stünden, werde für die traditionellen Institute schmerzhaft sein, aber weitgehend verkraftbar, schätzt die LBBW. Eine starke Position hat sich zum Beispiel Alipay, der Bezahldienst des chinesischen Onlinehandelkonzerns Alibaba, erarbeitet, sowie der Internetkonzern Tencent, der per Wechat Bezahlfunktionen anbietet. Kreditinstitute verfügten über die bessere Marktposition und seien in der Lage, sich anzupassen und mit den neuen Mitbewerbern mitzuhalten, etwa über Zinsen. Die sind nämlich für Libra nicht geplant. Gleichwohl hätten Banken unter anderem mit dem Verlust von Retailkunden und Einlagen zu kämpfen, was mit höheren Kosten und Volatilität bei der Refinanzierung einhergehen könnte.

Die ohnehin angespannte Lage der Kreditwirtschaft würde dies weiter verschärfen, wäre aber im Vergleich mit den - wenn auch als weniger realistisch erachteten - Alternativen noch komfortabel. Denn im zweiten Fall könnten Banken gezwungen sein, Big Techs wegen ihrer höher entwickelten Datenanalysefähigkeit Bonitätseinstufungen von potenziellen Kreditnehmern abzukaufen. Oder, schlimmer noch, die Techunternehmen böten Kredite gleich selbst an. Das dritte Szenario des IWF, das die LBBW als am unwahrscheinlichsten einschätzt, würde das Ende des Bankensektors bedeuten: seine Übernahme durch Big Techs.

Erfolg von Wechat und Alipay

Welches Szenario sich auch immer bewahrheitet, die von der Digitalisierung, sozialen Netzwerken sowie den hohen Ansprüchen an Konsum und Bequemlichkeit angestoßenen Effekte, die zum Aufkommen digitaler Währungen führten, seien irreversibel, befinden die Studienautoren. Das zeige der Aufstieg der chinesischen Anbieter: Der Erfolg der integrierten Bezahlsysteme in den Social-Media-Angeboten sollte Banken auch in Europa zu denken geben, wie die Autoren schreiben. Trotz der Existenz staatlich geschützter und geförderter Banken laufe mittlerweile der gesamte Zahlungsverkehr von Privatleuten und Kleinunternehmen in China über diese Systeme.

Auf die schützende Hand durch die Regulierer könne die Finanzbranche nicht mehr hoffen, glaubt die LBBW. Arbeitspapieren der Bank für Internationalen Zahlungsausgleich (BIZ) nach zu urteilen gingen diese "im Zweifel eher davon aus, dass die Big-Tech-Firmen dann zu regulierten Finanzinstituten mutieren", heißt es. Regulatorische Weichenstellungen wie die Zahlungsdiensterichtlinie PSD2, die Kontoinformations- und Zahlungsauslösediensten Zugang zum Bankkonto über definierte Schnittstellen verschafft, wenn der Kunde dem zustimmt, beschleunigten die Marktveränderungen noch.

Die Autoren weisen auf die Gefahr von Fehleinschätzungen durch etablierter Akteure hin: "Wir wollen davor warnen, die Geschwindigkeit, die hohe Bedeutung von Vernetzung und bequeme Handhabung (,Convenience') auch im Zahlungsverkehr zu unterschätzen und die Bedeutung des Datenschutzes für Nutzer in außereuropäischen Ländern zu überschätzen."

Kontaktloses Bezahlen mit Karte und Smartphone werde weiter an Bedeutung gewinnen, die Verbreitung von Smartphones zu veränderten Einkaufsgewohnheiten und neuen Bezahlmethoden führen. Die Akzeptanz von elektronischem Geld werde zunehmen, weil Big Techs in besonderem Maße von Netzwerkeffekten profitierten: Daten verheißen mehr Nutzen, je mehr Daten hinzukommen und verknüpft werden können. So wachsen die Zahlen der Nutzer von Wechat, Alipay und Facebook seit Jahren kontinuierlich (siehe Grafik). Die LBBW hält es gar für denkbar, dass Nutzer privaten Anbietern mehr Vertrauen entgegenbringen als Zentralbanken einzelner Länder.

Sparen über Facebook-Geld

In einer weiteren Analyse skizziert die DZ Bank vier Verwendungsmöglichkeiten von Libra, deren Effekte umso stärker ausfallen würden, je weiter die Digitalwährung über die Nutzung als reines Transaktionsinstrument hinausginge. In der engsten Variante beschränkte sich Libra auf die Tätigkeit als Krypto-Zahlungsdienstleister, über den binnen Sekunden Geld in alle Welt verschickt werden können soll. Damit wäre Libra ein Wettbewerber von vielen. Eine zweite Möglichkeit wäre der Analyse zufolge, dass Libra als Wertaufbewahrungsmittel genutzt wird: "Gerade für Menschen, die sich mit einer schwachen nationalen Währung konfrontiert sehen, könnte es darüber hinaus attraktiv sein, Libra aus Gründen der Wertaufbewahrung zu halten." Voraussetzung dafür wäre, dass Libra als stabil betrachtet wird und Wechselgebühren gering ausfallen, wie der Bericht festhält.

Setzte sich Libra als alltägliches Zahlungsmittel durch, etwa beim Bäcker, im Supermarkt und Taxi, könnte drittens die eigene Währung mehr und mehr ersetzt werden - insbesondere dann, wenn die Lohn- und Preissetzung auf Libra-Basis erfolgt. Damit verlöre die Zentralbank an Schlagkraft, weil ihr die Geldmengensteuerung entgleiten würde. "Schließlich hat die Zentralbank lediglich Einfluss auf das Geldangebot der zugehörigen Währung, nicht aber über den Umfang der in der Volkswirtschaft umlaufenden Libra."

Altwährung überflüssig

Im weitreichendsten, vierten Fall entwickelt sich Libra zu einem "neuen Ökosystem" im Finanzdienstleistungsbereich. Die DZ Bank sieht das als von den Initiatoren durchaus angepeiltes und im Libra-Weißbuch festgehaltenes Ziel, ein vollumfängliches Geld- und Finanzsystem zu schaffen. "Im Extremfall würden Zentralbanken irrelevant und die eigene Landeswährung gänzlich überflüssig. In einer Finanzkrise stünde dann kein (heimischer) ,Lender of Last Resort` mehr zur Verfügung, der die Banken und Finanzinstitute mit frischer Liquidität versorgen könnte", gibt der Studienverfasser zu bedenken.

Auch treibt ihn die Frage um, was im Falle einer Libra-Krise passieren würde, die etwa durch den Ausfall eines wichtigen Mitglieds der Libra Association oder eines Datenskandals ausgelöst werden könnte. Obwohl Libra als Stable Coin ausgelegt ist, der an einen Währungskorb gekoppelt und über einen Reservefonds, bestehend aus Bankeinlagen und kurzlaufenden Staatsanleihen, abgesichert sein soll, bestehe keine Garantie für einen stabilen Kurs. Könnten bei traditionellen Währungen Notenbanken eingreifen, so sei das bei Libra nicht möglich.

urn:contentItem:5WS4-WB01-JBJ9-H563-00000-00Banken, werdet Vorreiter im Zahlungssektor!2019-08-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:16ZLexisNexisGASTBEITRAGS. 4Banken, werdet Vorreiter im Zahlungssektor!Michael Salmony, Executive Adviser to the Board des Zahlungsabwicklers Equensworldline

Börsen-Zeitung, 8.8.2019

Banken machen sich zunehmend Sorgen, die Kontrolle über die Entwicklungen im Zahlungsverkehr zu verlieren. Diese Bedenken sind sicherlich berechtigt, denn jüngste Entwicklungen haben dazu geführt, dass die Tagesordnung der Banken zunehmend von den Anforderungen anderer gelenkt wird.

Banken mussten oftmals die von anderen getriebenen Veränderungen umsetzen - unter großem Zeitdruck und mit hohen Kosten. Beispiele dafür sind die Vorgaben der Regulierungsbehörden (PSD 2, Sepa) und des Handels (paneuropäische Lösungen) sowie die Einführung neuer Technologien und die Herausforderung durch neue Wettbewerber (Fintech, Challenger Banks, Big Tech) im Zahlungssektor. Banken klagen oft über die Mühe, Schritt zu halten. Vielleicht wäre es für Kunden und die Banken selbst daher hilfreich, die Agenda wieder mehr selber zu steuern und vorwärts zu treiben. Damit wären Banken weniger getrieben, und Kundenlösungen würden schneller auf den Markt kommen.

Nur beobachten reicht nicht

Viele Banken beobachten neue Entwicklungen und übernehmen bewusst ausgewählte Veränderungen, die auf die Bedürfnisse des Marktes reagieren und zu ihrer Strategie passen. Dies ist ein guter erster Schritt, er ist jedoch noch weit davon entfernt, auf diesem Weg "die Kontrolle zurückzugewinnen", da dies die Branche nicht ausreichend prägt und formt. Dieses Agieren entspricht mehr der Rolle eines Mitläufers, bestenfalls einem freiwilligen Engagement, als der Rolle eines Vorreiters und Gestalters. Die auf diesem Wege identifizierten Themen werden in der Regel eher von einzelnen Banken oder Bankengruppen (zum Beispiel als regionale Lösung) aufgegriffen. Daher gibt es eine Fragmentierung der Branche, und es entwickelt sich keine gemeinsame Initiative.

Besser wäre es, die Entwicklungen gemeinsam mit den anderen Akteuren des Zahlungssektors aktiv und zeitnah zu gestalten. Allerdings ist dies für einzelne Banken mit begrenzten Ressourcen nicht immer einfach, und für Bankengruppen kann es aus Wettbewerbsgründen schwierig sein. Für eine ganze Branche ist es bedeutend schwerer, sich gemeinsam zu bewegen, da sich viele Akteure miteinander abstimmen müssen.

Um es mit einer Metapher zu sagen: Banken werden nie von der Schildkröte zum Hasen werden - und das sollten sie auch nicht. Denn: Zuverlässigkeit, Stabilität und Compliance sind ein wesentlicher Vorteil der Banken gegenüber den anderen Marktteilnehmern. Aber es wäre zu überlegen, ob man die Initiative durch intelligente Ansätze zurückgewinnen könnte und weniger den Entwicklungen hinterherlaufen müsste.

Dies erfordert einen strategischen Ansatz, der es schafft, potenziell größere zukünftige Gewinne und strategische Positionen mit den aktuellen Unsicherheiten und möglicherweise sogar anfänglichen Verlusten in Einklang zu bringen. Es ist wichtig, das Gesamtbild zu betrachten, denn bei einer echten unternehmerischen Führung geht es darum, Entscheidungen zu treffen, ohne alle Fakten - zum Beispiel, ob es einen kurzfristigen Business Case geben und worauf er basieren wird - zu kennen, und ohne die 100-prozentige Garantie, die richtige Wahl zu treffen.

Banken haben in der Vergangenheit gezeigt, dass dies möglich ist. Ein Beispiel ist iDeal, vor mehr als zehn Jahren von niederländischen Banken gegründet. iDeal ist eine erstklassige Lösung für Online-Zahlungen, die sich bis heute gegen alle Wettbewerber durchgesetzt hat und erstaunliche Wachstumsraten aufweist. Überdies sahen skandinavische Banken die Notwendigkeit und Möglichkeit, führende Lösungen für bankbasierte Identität (BankID) und mobile Lösungen (Swish) zu entwickeln. Ebenjene Entwicklungen haben unter anderem dafür gesorgt, dass Kundenbeziehungen, Daten und Gewinne auch weiter bei den Banken liegen.

Die Kontrolle zurückerobern

Die Frage ist, wie ein solcher neuer, proaktiver Ansatz in der Praxis funktionieren könnte. Die folgenden Schritte bilden einen Anfang:

1. Diagnose

Ein erster Schritt ist eine offene Diskussion innerhalb der wichtigsten Bankengemeinschaften. Dabei sollte diskutiert werden, wie Banken durch eine proaktive Strategie, die neue und zukünftige Entwicklungen beinhaltet, die Kontrolle wiedererlangen können, bevor jemand sie in eine bestimmte Richtung drängt. Außerdem wäre es sinnvoll, eine "Koalition von Willigen" aufzustellen, die alle dazu bereit sind, die weiteren Entwicklungen tatkräftig mitzugestalten.

2. Strategie

Als nächsten Schritt sollten Banken eine gemeinsame Initiative aller Bankengruppen ins Leben rufen, um die aktuell anstehenden Zukunftsvisionen zu untersuchen und den Sektor gemeinschaftlich voranzubringen. Der neue Ansatz sollte beispielsweise auf aktuellen Entwicklungen wie Open Banking und Instant Payment aufbauen, denn dies sind Themen, bei denen Europa weltweit führend ist. Natürlich wird es zwischen den Gemeinschaften und unter Banken unterschiedliche Auffassungen darüber geben, wie es diesbezüglich weitergeht, aber es ist unbedingt notwendig, lokale und individuelle Interessen zum Wohle des gesamten Sektors und Europas beiseitezulegen.

3. Umsetzung

Wenn der Wille zu mutigem Handeln vorhanden ist, sollten die Ergebnisse dieses gemeinsamen Ansatzes selbstbewusst mit Regulierungsbehörden diskutiert werden. Wenn die Regulierungsbehörden sehen, dass die Banken schneller Veränderungen vornehmen, werden sie weniger Anreiz haben, eine präventive Regulierung zu entwickeln oder gegen das vorzugehen, was sie als (bevorstehendes) Marktversagen ansehen. Regulatoren können den Prozess noch stärker moderieren und einen größeren Anteil an der Problemlösung haben. Es gewinnen alle - insbesondere Kunden und die Banken selbst.

----

Michael Salmony, Executive Adviser to the Board des Zahlungsabwicklers Equensworldline

Bankers' preference for the former vice president comes even as the Trump administration has delivered in a significant way for the banks. Executives and employees at the nation’s biggest banks are giving a boost to former Vice President Joe Biden's campai...

Bankers' preference for the former vice president comes even as the Trump administration has delivered in a significant way for the banks. Executives and employees at the nation’s biggest banks are giving a boost to former Vice President Joe Biden's campaign for the White House, despite economic policies under President Donald Trump that produced record profits for the industry. Contributions from individuals affiliated with the six largest lenders total $907,216 for Biden and $293,434 for Trump, according to a POLITICO review of campaign finance data. Biden has a significant fundraising advantage at every one of the banks — JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, Citigroup, Wells Fargo, Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley. Their preference for the former vice president comes even as Trump's administration has delivered in a significant way for the banks — making them among the main beneficiaries of his 40 percent cut in the corporate tax rate and easing Obama-era regulations. Biden has pledged to repeal some of those tax cuts and impose new fees on large financial institutions. But in an era of growing social and racial unrest, as well as income inequality, many bankers are voting beyond their wallets in the belief that Trump is stoking those divisions, industry experts say. Many in the industry are embracing Biden’s approaches to racial equity, foreign affairs and other areas where his tone is more aligned with the leaders of global financial institutions. "These contributions speak to the deep unease Democrats and many independents have with national policy on personal priorities such as equality, civility and constitutionality," said Federal Financial Analytics managing partner Karen Petrou, who advises bank executives on policy. The bankers, she said, are "expressing themselves as well as their company’s priorities when they make contributions." To be sure, Biden is also a known entity to Wall Street and benefits from his longtime closeness to the financial industry. While representing Delaware in the Senate, he supported bankruptcy legislation that made it harder for consumers to escape credit card debt. More recently, he attracted controversy for telling wealthy donors at a 2019 fundraiser that "no one's standard of living will change, nothing would fundamentally change" for them. And employees at the megabanks also showed a preference for former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton over Trump in 2016 — she outraised him by more than 10 to 1 among these same companies. But they put their money behind Republican Mitt Romney when he ran against President Barack Obama and Biden in 2012. The figures, aggregated by the Center for Responsive Politics, cover not only high-profile executives but also other employees at the sprawling, international corporations. They underscore a view in the banking industry that Biden would govern as a moderate despite the influence of Wall Street watchdogs like Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.). The contributions analyzed for this story came from individual donors at the banks and were not directed by the companies themselves, which operate separate political action committees that help fund congressional campaigns. The wave of contributions has emerged as Biden, who will accept the Democratic presidential nomination during the party's convention next week, takes the lead over Trump in national and battleground state polls. Trump campaign spokesperson Samantha Zager said the president is counting on ordinary voters to win reelection. “President Trump’s campaign is powered by everyday Americans who have benefited from his bold leadership," she said. "Joe Biden has Big Tech, Big Pharma, and Big Banks in his pocket, and the Trump campaign still outraised him in July — not to mention we have real voter enthusiasm in our corner. President Trump will continue to prioritize hardworking Americans while Joe Biden looks out for himself.” Jason Pye, vice president of legislative affairs at FreedomWorks, a conservative group, had another explanation for Biden's popularity with bankers: "It's no secret that big businesses, including big financial institutions, tend to benefit from big government policies. They're able to insulate themselves from regulation to some degree because they can afford the cost of compliance that leaves smaller institutions out in the cold." Several senior leaders at the big banks have contributed money to Biden’s campaign, including Goldman Sachs CFO Stephen Scherr and JPMorgan general counsel Stacey Friedman. Goldman Sachs Japan Vice Chair Kathy Matsui contributed $54,600 to the Biden Victory Fund, Biden's joint fundraising operation with the Democratic National Committee. Morgan Stanley Vice Chair Thomas Nides and Wells Fargo Vice Chairman of Public Affairs Bill Daley — both former Obama administration officials — have also contributed to Biden's campaign. While Biden has shied away from demonizing Wall Street like Warren and some other Democrats, he has pledged to raise taxes on large financial institutions and other corporations after Trump slashed the rate to 21 percent from 35 percent in 2017, helping deliver a 44 percent surge in banking industry profits in 2018. That’s the top concern of bank lobbyists who are starting to game out how Washington would approach the industry if Democrats take back power. Yet Paul Thornell, former managing director for federal government affairs at Citigroup, said banking executives aren’t just focused on things like tax policy when it comes to showing their support for a candidate. “They’re looking at character and how these two conduct themselves as leaders,” said Thornell, now a principal at government relations firm Mehlman Castagnetti Rosen & Thomas. “They’re looking at the issues that Trump has decided to align himself with versus the issues they think Biden would give voice to, which are probably more in line with where they are personally, the brand and reputation of their firms and the issues their employees care about.” Still, any perceived coziness between Biden and bankers is a potential political problem as the former vice president faces pressure from progressives to crack down on big business. One Biden official said teachers are the top profession that donates to his campaign. "Wall Street bankers and hedge fund managers didn't build this country — the American middle class did," Biden spokesperson Andrew Bates said. "Donald Trump has turned his back on families struggling to get by throughout his presidency, passing a multitrillion-dollar tax giveaway to the wealthy and plunging manufacturing into a recession while creating new incentives for outsourcing American jobs — whereas Joe Biden is running to ensure that our economy rewards work, not just wealth, which is why his campaign is powered by small, grassroots donations." Indeed, a Biden administration will likely pursue stricter banking regulation than has Trump, though it's not expected to be the kind of sea change that occurred under Obama. At that time, the global economy was reeling from a financial crisis created by Wall Street, and Democrats responded by overhauling bank regulation with the landmark 2010 Dodd-Frank Act. Now, bank lobbyists say the Biden campaign’s recent economic proposals, including those released in partnership with Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.), haven’t been that surprising or threatening. Bank representatives see lots of issues where they can have constructive conversations with Democrats. They include responding to climate change, improving corporate diversity and supporting small business. Big banks have also joined the fight against Big Tech by lobbying to stop technology companies from obtaining bank charters. Lobbyists expect Democrats to put more pressure on private equity firms than big banks, which were public enemy No. 1 when Biden became vice president in 2009. The dynamic was on display last month when Sen. Sherrod Brown (D-Ohio) — who proposed breaking up the banks after the 2008 crisis — spoke on a Goldman Sachs-hosted Zoom call commemorating the graduation of entrepreneurs from the company's “10,000 Small Businesses” program. Brown, who would likely chair the Senate Banking Committee if Democrats won back the Senate, appeared with Goldman CEO David Solomon. Brown scolded Solomon for stock buybacks the bank pursued thanks to the Trump tax cuts but he also praised the bank’s small business efforts in Ohio. “I hope you’ll follow up with a commitment to invest more of your, I would say, immense resources in the real economy and communities that often get overlooked by Wall Street,” Brown said. “This is an example of Goldman doing that.” Capital Alpha Partners director Ian Katz said there are competing forces at play when it comes to how the banking industry views Biden. Biden and his regulators would generally favor tighter regulation. But Trump has been harder for banks to predict because of his populist tendencies. “There's also the possibility that while bankers prefer Trump on matters affecting their industry, they may prefer Biden on most other things,” Katz said. “If that's the case, they could lean toward Biden because they prefer him on most matters, and while he may be less friendly than Trump is to banks, they don't think he'll be dangerously unfriendly. So when they take everything into account, they may lean toward Biden.”

urn:contentItem:5F40-SKV1-JD35-2124-00000-00Bankers fight for relevance in tech M&A2014-09-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:16ZLexisNexisBankers fight for relevance in tech M&ADavid Rothnie

Silicon Valley's deal boom is noteworthy because in many cases, investment banks aren't involved, writes David Rothnie. Staying relevant in this sector runs against the short term cost control mantra prevalent in banking today.

Bankers hate missing out on a deal boom. M&A in the global technology sector has seen more than $185bn of deals announced so far this year, the most since before the global financial crisis. But at the same time, acquisitive companies are relying on investment banks for advice less and less. Data from Dealogic shows that 70% of deals above $100m in 2014 have been conducted without advisers, compared with 27% 10 years ago.

While big investment banks have enjoyed a starting role in the big tech IPOs, when it comes to deal making, there are instances this year when they were hired to play a bit part "" either coming in after the deal had been negotiated, or being asked to give a fairness opinion. In some case, they missed out on the action altogether. Oracle did not use any banking advice when it acquired Microsystems in a $6.5bn deal in June, the biggest transaction not involving advisers since 2011, when Microsoft bought Skype from SilverLake Partners for $8bn.

At the same time, the sector is also embracing the broader trend of firms using boutique advisers. The investment banking industry stood up and really took note this year when Facebook paid $19bn for WhatsApp in a transaction that was agreed between the two companies' founders. Facebook used Allen & Company and Morgan Stanleyadvised WhatsApp but sources close to the deal say that both banks were brought in at a late stage after the company founders had negotiated the deal. That followed Google's $3.4bn acquisition NestLabs, for which it used Lazard for a fairness opinion, but did the nuts and bolts of the negotiations and execution using its own team. Nestlabs did not use an adviser. Disintermediation?

This has led some to suggest that banks are being disintermediated as tech firms rely on their own personal relationships to source deals and their growing in-house teams to execute them.

It is certainly the case that the tight knit community in Silicon Valley means that many private deals are negotiated between founders, with no need to use investment banks. Also, it's true that technology M&A is not a business every bank can be successful in. The bulk of technology M&A is US-based, where a handful of top bankers hold the relationships. Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanleyhave slugged it out for the last decade, trading bragging rights on the biggest IPO and merger deals. While Goldman was lead on the Twitter IPO, Morgan Stanleyled Facebook's listing.

Goldman and Morgan Stanleyare streets ahead in the league tables. Morgan Stanleyis currently top, having advised on 24 deals with a value of $34.2bn, while Goldman has worked on 28 deals with a value of $30bn, according to Dealogic. Their nearest bulge-bracket competitor is Bank of AmericaMerrill Lynch, which has advised on 20 global technology deals worth $17.6bn. JP Morgan is one of the few top firms investing in its global technology team after identifying the sector as a growth business.

It is no coincidence that both of the top firms also have the best advisory franchises, which counts for something even in the maverick world of Silicon Valley. Being able to advise companies on high level strategic issues is crucial, rather than chasing deals once they have been announced like a dog after a butcher's van. Last year, Goldman Sachs won a starring role on Apple's blockbuster bond sale, scooping more fees than any of the other bookrunners because it was advising the board of Apple on calls by shareholders for a share buyback. This was clearly not an M&A transaction, but it required advice, and that is what Goldman and Morgan Stanleysell in their corporate finance businesses.

Allen & Company, which is third in the global M&A rankings for technology, decided a decade ago that it was going to move into technology, and the move has paid off, although the time scale shows the patience that is required. The Facebook-Whatsapp mandate counted for a big chunk of the year's ranking, but Allen has also worked on other recent prestige mandates such as the LinkedIn and Twitter IPOs. Picking winners

Firms who adopt a half-hearted attitude to M&A, whether by not covering clients assiduously enough, or offering M&A as a bolt-on service, will fail. For banks to remain relevant, they need to spot future winners, as well as covering existing large firms and big deals. Goldman and Morgan Stanleyhave spent time and resources covering the venture capital firms active in Silicon Valley, treating them as proper clients in the way many banks treat financial sponsors. In a sign of the importance Goldman attaches to this, a year ago it appointed Stuart Bernstein, one of its long standing partners, as head of its venture capital coverage group.

The particular challenge posed by global technology companies is that success means banks picking the winners of the future and that does not necessarily sit well with the new pragmatism at work in investment banks. With the cost of capital rising in the new regulatory environment, banks are being more ruthless in prioritising the clients they already serve "" those which use the most services and pay it the biggest fees "" and are losing the tail of unprofitable ones. They are not chasing new clients or launching new costly sector initiatives.

Banks may find their ability to pick early stage winners may be impaired as bankers will be less prepared to stick their neck out and wage the battle internally for a bank to back a new client which may not immediately be profitable. Like Goldman, Morgan Stanleyhas a strong track record in the sector. The bank was an early backer of Patrick Drahi, the founder and chairman of French telecoms group Altice, a bet that has resulted in a long-standing relationship. Boutique drift

Then there is the matter of senior staffers leaving big banks. Many of the world's top rainmakers made their name advising on big deals in the technology, media and telecoms sectors, and the current generational shift means that big banks are losing some of their most experienced bankers either to clients or boutiques.

Top Morgan Stanleybankers Paul Taubmann and Scott Matlock, who represented some of the bank's biggest clients in TMT, have set up their own boutique, while Altice hired Johannes Groeller and Emmanuel Gueroult from Morgan Stanley. Meanwhile, Facebook has lured staff away from Credit Suisse and Jefferies to work in its corporate development teams.

Earlier this year, Goldman reshuffled its tech team in anticipation of a rise in deal flow, moving Dan Dees, who had run the firm's Asian investment banking business, forging relationships with Alibaba, to co-head the global TMT group in San Francisco with Anthony Noto. The timing turned out to be fortuitous because a few months later Noto, a senior partner who featured on the Twitter IPO, left the firm to join hedge fund Coatue Management LLC before being appointed CFO of Twitter in July.

In contrast with Silicon Valley, which is the centre of global technology and therefore the hub of the current M&A boom, banks allocate fewer resources to Europe, and that means there is a smaller talent pool (and fewer deals to go around). Boutiques such as Qatalyst Partners and Alma Partners are grabbing a bigger share of small-cap deals, but they are also winning business higher up the food chain. For example France's Alcatel-Lucent uses Ondra Partners as its retained financial adviser. Alcatel's CEO Michel Combes knows Ondra Partners well, but the appointment is also further evidence of a dearth of tech-focused coverage efforts by big banks in Europe. Where are the deals?

This is perhaps no accident. Since the financial crisis, bank have become more adept at deploying resources to where they are most needed, and in Europe, the bulk of the M&A action has taken place in the media and telecom sectors, where convergence has driven deal flow in the form of telecoms companies looking to provide media content and vice versa. While the outside world may perceive a bank has a weakness in technology, the bank itself will not be concerned as long as it is punching its weight in telecoms M&A, for example.

This does not alter the fact that some banks will baulk at making the necessary investment to make them winners in technology M&A, because it just looks like a lot of cost for very little reward. Outside of Morgan Stanleyand Goldman Sachs, the stars are thinly dispersed "" Philippe Cerf at Credit Suisse is highly regarded by clients, as is Jean Tardy-Joubert at Qatalyst. There has been little in the way of hiring, with some bankers leaving firms in frustration at a lack of deal opportunities. Last year Mark Fisher, who was co-head of technology at Jefferies, which has expanded its technology footprint, left to join boutique Quayle Munro because "there simply weren't enough deals to go around," according to one source familiar with his plans. A maturing market

As the global technology sector has undergone a transformation, so too has the banking structure that supports it. Boutiques are on the rise, and some companies have the resources to handle more deals in-house. But as the industry moves towards the next phase of maturity it will embrace more banking products "" witness bond deals by Apple and the IPO of Facebook as milestones of corporate development. And the CEOs of these behemoths will gradually shed the mentality that led them to blaze a trail as they adopt a more considered view of dealmaking under pressure from public investors.

The Facebook acquisition of Whatsapp took the market by surprise, and was executed by a public company at an eye-watering valuation. Speaking on a panel at a bank conference earlier this year, Jeffrey Ubben, founder of activist investor ValueAct Capital, offered his opinion of the free-spending tech M&A boom as "just a bunch of 26 year olds throwing their money around and making their friends rich."

As tech tyros grow up in public they will rely more, not less on investment banks. Those betting on a long-term decline of big banks' tech practices are wide of the mark. Bankers say they expect more public deals featuring a full roster of advisers to be announced before year-end and that the proportion of non-advised tech deals will revert to the norm.

The specialist nature of the tech industry means that only those banks that can offer valuable advice and have the commitment to unearthing new industry winners will thrive. And that is as it should be. Banks will ignore this at their peril or the tech giants will take their business as well as their staff.

urn:contentItem:5V95-MMD1-JCMN-Y29W-00000-00Bankers ready for the next challenge2019-01-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:16ZLexisNexisBankers ready for the next challenge

Jan 27, 2019( The Hindu Business Line: http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/ Delivered by Newstex) The last two-and-a-half decades have been truly eventful for the Indian banking industry. The level of competition and price discovery that we see today has its roots in 1994, when six banks in the private sector were licensed to operate: they are the major competitors of state-run banks today. Further, the Narasimham Committee of 1991 and 1998 and subsequent reform measures have changed the landscape of Indian banking.Some of these reforms include the lowering of the CRR and the SLR; framing of prudential norms for income recognition and asset classification; introduction of capital adequacy norms; deregulation of interest rates; strengthening of legal and institutional framework for speeding the process of recovery of debts; fostering competition by giving licences to new banks in the private sector; access to capital markets for banks; structural reorganisation in the banking sector; strengthening banking supervision; and regulatory oversight of banks.The Indian financial sector is dominated by banks.

For a growing economy like India, there is a huge requirement of credit in almost all the sectors. To meet the financing needs of the economy, Indian banking needs to be healthy and robust. The continuous disintermediation effort by the government has boosted the growth of non-bank channels (including corporate bond market and capital markets) to meet the partial funding requirement of corporates.Credit penetration (Credit-GDP ratio) of the banking sector has substantially increased to 51.42 per cent in 2017-18 from only 20.20 per cent in 1992-93. Similarly, deposit penetration by the banking sector (Deposit-GDP) has grown from 35.7 per cent in 1992-93 to 68.12 per cent in 2017-18. These statistics clearly portray the importance of the banking sector to the Indian economy.VulnerabilitiesIn the absence of any credible term lending institution, banks have taken up the onus of providing short-term as well as long-term funding to projects and industries. However, excessive reliance of the economy on the banking sector for long-term funding requirements has made it vulnerable to economic and geopolitical contagion. However, owing to tight regulatory and prudent measures, Indian banking proved resilient to the sub-prime crisis of 2007-08, but a prolonged economic slowdown and weak corporate balance sheets have clouded the Indian banking sector in the past few years.The introduction of niche banking and the entry of non-bank fintech and big-tech companies in the banking domain have further intensified competition in the sector. In the technological advancement process, Indian banking has worked to optimise customer experience. As a favourable demography will reshape the future of Indian banking, banks are already in the process of understanding the mindset of new millennial and Generation-Z customers who are less loyal and demand omni channel seamless service.The emergence of newer capabilities such as data analytics, cloud computing, blockchain technology, artificial intelligence, cyber security, robotics, automation, NLP and language support, humanoids, holographic banking and robo-advisory, voice and chatbot are the new reality. To meet the banking and non-banking requirements of these young customers, SBI has launched the country's first integrated lifestyle and banking digital platform 'YONO'. Other banks are also working on enhancing customer experience and customers' life cycle requirements are getting integrated with CRM applications.Challenges, opportunitiesOn the other hand, India is home to 11 per cent of globally unbanked adults. (According to the World Bank's, Global Findex Database 2017, among the 1.7 billion unbanked adults globally, 187 million are from India.) The role of Indian banking in driving the financial inclusion agenda of the government has been lauded in international forums. As on January 2, 2019, about 33.73 crore PMJDY accounts have been opened, and the JAM (Jan Dhan, Aadhaar, and Mobile) initiative of the government has been able to bring the mass unbanked into the financial services net. These newly boarded customers have opened up a plethora of opportunities for banks to expand their profitable retail business as these new customers deserve numerous other services from banks apart from opening bank accounts. To meet the requirements of this vast customer base, Indian banks need to equip themselves with the latest technology to serve the needs of those unbanked as well as under-banked segments.The consolidation of state-run banks has been one of the most discussed topics in the past two-and-a-half decades. Consolidation, by its very nature, is challenging. In the past, not all mergers and consolidations have been successful. Some of the important challenges in human resources, technology and regulatory fronts need to be properly evaluated in advance to avoid any pitfall for a successful consolidation going forward. The government has identified and is stabilising some of the weak state-run banks by resolving their bad-loans issue and adequately recapitalising them before embarking on a consolidation plan.The Indian banking regulator has been vigilant in maintaining the health of the sector. However, a prolonged economic slowdown has led to the twin balance-sheet problem as banking is no more an isolated sector. The banking sector has to constantly upgrade and re-orient itself to tide over the balance-sheet mismatch crisis. The introduction of the long-awaited Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC) 2016 has facilitated faster resolution by offering a time-bound resolution through the NCLT. Going forward, prudent management and economic recovery are likely to bring cheer to the system.In these years, many positive developments have happened in relation to governance aspects of Indian banks. Effective corporate governance, so critical to the functioning of the banking sector and the economy as a whole, has shown remarkable and sustainable coming of age. We are entering an exciting and challenging phase of banking in India, and fortunately the major players and various stakeholders appear eminently ready for the challenge.The author is SBI Chairman

urn:contentItem:5WCG-14N1-DY19-C160-00000-00Bankers reckon with 'serious threat' of Facebook2019-06-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:17ZLexisNexisBankers reckon with 'serious threat' of FacebookJames Eyers

The peak body for the payments industry says bank investment in real-time payments will help them repel Facebook - but bankers are unsure.

Facebook's plans to launch a digital wallet and cryptocurrency have been met with dread by bank insiders fearful of losing revenue and customer relationships, even as the peak body for the payments industry said the big four are well prepared to repel the threat.

Anthony Healy, a senior executive at National Australia Bank, described the plans a "serious threat", given the global technology platform's "immense resources" and "huge amount of users".

The major banks make around $8 billion each year, or around 7 per cent of their total revenue, from payments, according to Morgan Stanley.

The CEO of the Australian Payments Network, Andy White, said the big banks are well-placed to defend this revenue given their substantial investment in real-time payments infrastructure and improved digital banking services.

He also questioned whether Australian consumers would really want to transact in Libra, the new cryptocurrency Facebook is creating with 28 global partners.

"The vast majority of Australians dealing in Australian dollars do so digitally, with clear entry and exit points where they can pay and take payment through their bank accounts, and this now in real-time through NPP [the new payments platform]," Mr White said.

"I suppose the question for them is do they need an alternative such as Libra - what's the value add for them? That question is obviously different for the unbanked community in developing markets."

The Reserve Bank last week urged the banks to put more payments volume through the real-time payments system, which the banks spent more than $1 billion to build, in part to protect them from disruptive forces including blockchain-based payments systems like the one being built by Facebook.

"Australian consumers can access their bank accounts in real time through NPP," Mr White said. "Such real-time payments have significant value to the underlying Australian economy because the receiver can use funds immediately, this is a value add of NPP compared to existing payment rails."

Mr Healy, NAB's chief customer officer of business and private banking, said all of the banks "will be keeping a close eye on [Facebook] as it develops and will be watching to see if it emerges as a real threat and imposing proposition''.

"Developments like this give us the opportunity to learn and also reinforce the need for us to continue innovating to provide our customers with the best experiences," he said.

Sources inside other major banks said the technology giant's technical white papers published on Tuesday night were being closely scrutinised by internal strategy teams.

"People are very aware of the threat of big tech platforms and have been more concerned about that than neobanks or P2P lenders," said one bank insider. "We aren't sure they will be successful, but we have thought for a while that the platform companies like Amazon, Google or Facebook will be the ones that disrupt us - and here we are.

"As a bank you don't want to lose control of payments."

Investment bank Morgan Stanley said earlier this month that on top of the direct payment fees received by banks, payments influence $22 billion, or 20 per cent, of banking industry revenue and this is under threat by the emergence of digital wallets on smartphones offered by global technology companies.

Another banker in one of the big four was more sanguine about the crypto-currency threat. "It's too early to know what the impact of Libra will be. This could just be a clever way for Facebook to sell more on their platform. Clearly it will be watched, but we aren't sure it's a threat. Time will tell, but the announcement hasn't caused any tidal wave of response in here."

Banks' revenue from payments is already under pressure from caps to interchange fees, which are paid by merchants, and ongoing scrutiny of credit cards by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission.

Morgan Stanley said if credit card interchange commissions and fees, and revenue from foreign exchange and merchant fees, were to fall by one-third, Commonwealth Bank's group revenue would fall 1 per cent, and profit would fall 2 per cent.

"The success of Afterpay, Zip, PayPal and others demonstrates that the current regulatory settings are pushing innovation in payments outside the regular bank and credit card channels," Morgan Stanley said.

Rocky Scopelliti, a futurist who sits on the Australian Payments Council, described Facebook's entry into payments as "an inevitable move, due to the role that social media is now playing throughout our lives".

He said the rise of Chinese fintech giant Alibaba Group, which owns Ant Financial, "shows what can happen when there is a diversification of service offerings across lifestyle processes. Millennials in China have shown the explosiveness of social media and payments coming together. There is a clearly a demographic appetite for the use of both services.

"Facebook's move will be one of the first global micro-payment services that may emerge, although I think it will be harder for them to translate it to point of sale in a store, because infrastructure needs to change to enable that to happen."

Facebook said on Tuesday that Mastercard and Visa are foundation partners in the Libra Association because they are keen to support merchants using their infrastructure who want to accept payments in Libra.
