In the UK, Matt Hancock has said that the law could be changed to fast track a vaccine before Christmas, while in the US Dr Anthony Fauci said a similar thing, stating that if the ongoing clinical trials were overwhelmingly positive, then a vaccine could arrive earlier than expected. To compliment these claims, human trials of the Oxford vaccine have now begun in the US. This was more than enough for investors - so much so, in fact, that it meant they could ignore the US saying it won't join in with the global, WHO-backed effort to develop and distribute a vaccine. Barratt Developments, one of the UK's biggest housebuilders, has told the City that demand has increased sharply since the lockdown eased. Barratt reported that reservations are running at 314 per week since the start of July, compared with 250 per week a year ago. Home completion are 62% higher than in 2019, as builders catch up with work delayed by the lockdown. Barratt says this increased activity is being stimulated by pent-up demand and the Stamp Duty holiday. However, it has still scrapped a 'special dividend' planned for 2021, after seeing profits nearly halve due to the pandemic. CEO David Thomas adds: "While COVID-19 has had a significant impact on our results, our priority has been to keep our people safe, mitigate the effect of the pandemic on our business and be able to emerge from the crisis in a resilient position. Although uncertainties remain, all of our sites are operational, we are seeing very strong consumer demand and our robust financial position means we enter the new financial year with cautious optimism. Now this is interesting - and bad news for first-time buyers: HSBC is planning to cut back its 'low-deposit' mortgages, following a surge of interest. My colleagues Kalyeena Makortoff and Patrick Collinson explain: HSBC, one of the last banks to offer low-deposit "90%" mortgages, is expected to restrict sales within days, in a move likely to leave first-time buyers struggling to find a loan. The bank's 400 mortgage advisers are currently flooded with applications from buyers, with customers forced to wait as long as three to four weeks to be interviewed by the bank. Meanwhile, the bank is opening a daily window of as little as half an hour in the morning for brokers to apply for loans before the daily allocation of money runs out. The Guardian understands that HSBC - which accounts for around 6.8% of the UK's mortgage market - has been trying to find responsible ways to curb high demand for its low-deposit mortgages. here's a note of caution from Andrew Montlake, managing director at UK mortgage broker, Coreco: "Two words: reality check. As strong as the property market is right now, it will not last. "Demand is understandably strong after lockdown and the added bonus of the stamp duty holiday, but unemployment is rising by the day and the economic outlook is highly uncertain as the furlough scheme ends. "In the final months of the year we will start to see a reversal in the current rate of house price growth, as the true impact of Covid-19 on the economy shows through Lucy Pendleton, property expert at independent estate agents James Pendleton, agrees that the stamp duty holiday is fuelling the housing market -- and pushing prices sharply higher: "Buyers emboldened by the stamp duty holiday have been engaged in a pitch battle for property, delivering a barnstorming recovery for the market. A stunning proportion of properties are now going for asking price or more, and offers are flooding in. It's like lockdown was a bad dream. "The number of buyer registrations is also holding up at a time of the year that would typically see a slowdown. "The late summer surge is particularly apparent in London where the greatest proportion of buyers will benefit from the maximum discount of £15,000. "For many, this emerging boom will mean paying so much more for a home that the extra cash eclipses the saving dished out by the Chancellor. That's more likely to happen the further up the chain you go and that's the beauty of this policy. It's great for first-time buyers but everyone's invited, and once people get it into their heads that they're moving, it's like an unstoppable force. People double down on that momentum when they then find a property they love and, armed with some extra cash, they find a way to stretch the seams of their pockets just a little bit more. Jonathan Hopper, CEO of Garrington Property Finders, says rural estate agents and surveyors have seen a surge in demand this summer. That includes families looking to quit the daily commuting rat race and move to a greener lifestyle, following the move to home working this year [despite the government's efforts to get everyone back to their old desks]. "In some areas the property industry is playing catch up. We're seeing good homes go under offer very quickly but transactions take longer - as demand for surveyors outstrips supply and conveyancing firms race to dial up their capacity to handle a fast-growing workload. "Prices are rising fastest among coastal and country properties as buyers planning for a new work-life balance built around less commuting seek more green space, fresh air and better value. Tobi Mancuso, director of property investment company Track Capital, warns that the government's stamp duty holiday could drive a house price bubble. That temporary cut lets buyers in England and Northern Ireland save £15,000 when buying a £500,000 house, so could drive demand for the next six months: "The chancellor's stamp duty holiday has launched the sale of the century, and properties are flying off the shelves as fast as they are getting listed. "Estate agents are rightly making hay while the sun shines, and house prices have accelerated to a new all-time high. Strap yourself in, because we're going to see a lot of records broken in the next few months. "The March 2021 date for the end of the stamp duty holiday feels a long way away, and it looks like the market is going to enjoy a long uplift. "The danger is that this frenzy could create a bubble in house prices that will be quickly deflated when stamp duty returns, so buyers should be wary of prices that feel over-inflated. Capital Economics' Hansen Lu points out that house prices inflation is back at pre-pandemic levels: This jump in UK house prices makes homes even less affordable. At 3.7% per year, prices are now rising much faster than incomes -- particularly as many people's earnings fell during the pandemic (because they were furloughed, lost their jobs, or saw work dry up). As this chart shows, we're heading back to price/earnings levels seen before the 2007 credit crunch: Here's the key points from Nationwide's house price report: Nationwide also predicts that house prices will keep rising this autumn, partly thanks to government's temporary stamp duty freeze [in England and Northern Ireland, anyway]. Chief economist Robert Gardner explains: "These trends look set to continue in the near term, further boosted by the recently announced stamp duty holiday, which will serve to bring some activity forward. But, a surge in unemployment in the coming months would then hit demand, he adds: "Most forecasters expect labour market conditions to weaken significantly in the quarters ahead as a result of the aftereffects of the pandemic and as government support schemes wind down. If this comes to pass, it would likely dampen housing activity once again in the quarters ahead. Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of the world economy, the financial markets, the eurozone and business. UK house prices have accelerated to a fresh record high, as the property market rebounds after the Covid-19 lockdown. New figures just released by Nationwide show that the cost of the average house surged by 2% in August alone, up to £224,123 from £220,935 in July. That's the biggest monthly rise since 2004 - and the highest recorded by Nationwide. On an annual basis, prices were 3.7% higher than a year ago -- a much faster rise than expected (economists had forecast a 0.5% monthly rise - and 2% year-on-year). Robert Gardner, Nationwide's chief economist, says 'behavioural shifts' are helping to drive the housing market, as some people look to move to a house better suited to home working. "UK house prices rose by 2.0% in August, after taking account of seasonal effects, following a 1.8% rise in July. This is the highest monthly rise since February 2004 (2.7%). As a result, annual house price growth accelerated to 3.7%, from 1.5% last month. "House prices have now reversed the losses recorded in May and June and are at a new all-time high. "The bounce back in prices reflects the unexpectedly rapid recovery in housing market activity since the easing of lockdown restrictions. "This rebound reflects a number of factors. Pent up demand is coming through, where decisions taken to move before lockdown are progressing. Behavioural shifts may also be boosting activity, as people reassess their housing needs and preferences as a result of life in lockdown. Our own research, conducted in May (link), indicated that around 15% of people surveyed were considering moving as a result of lockdown. "Moreover, social distancing does not appear to be having as much of a chilling effect as we might have feared, at least at this point. This comes just a day after the number of new mortgage approvals jumped by 40% in a month, up 26,000 in July to 66,300. Net mortgage lending rose by £2.7bn, the Bank of England reported on Tuesday. Details and reaction to follow... Also coming up today Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey will testify to parliament's Treasury Committee on the economic impact of Covid-19 this afternoon, alongside fellow policymakers Dame Colette Bowe, Alex Brazier, Dave Ramsden and Gertjan Vlieghe. It's quite a busy day for economic news, including new Spanish unemployment figures which will illustrate the impact of the pandemic on its tourism economy. The latest monthly US payroll changes from ADP will show how many jobs were created by American companies last month. Plus the latest oil inventory reports will show if energy demand rose or fell last week. After falling to a three-month low on Tuesday, the FTSE 100 is expected to recover somewhat today. The index is called up 50-ish points at 5903, having dropped by 101 yesterday. Last night, Wall Street closed at fresh record highs, with technology stocks continuing their remarkable ascent. Zoom is now worth more than IBM after posting a huge jump in revenues and users on Monday night. Apple's now worth more than the entire FTSE 100, having surged 80% this year. The agenda 7am BST: Nationwide's survey of UK house prices in August 8am BST: Spanish unemployment for August 1.15pm BST: The ADP survey of US private sector employment for August 2.30pm BST: Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey and colleagues at the Treasury committee 3pm BST: US factory orders for July 3.30pm BST: US weekly oil inventory figures 46275 false false Graeme Wearden A Macy's branch in New York. urn:contentItem:5SD3-6911-JBVM-Y024-00000-00Bank of Ireland's UK boss sees big tech firms as main rivals2018-05-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:16ZLexisNexisBUSINESS WEEK;NEWSPg. 2Bank of Ireland's UK boss sees big tech firms as main rivalsCharlie Weston

BIG technology companies present the largest challenge to conventional banks, the head of Bank of Ireland UK has said.

CEO Des Crowley said Google, Amazon, Facebook and Apple were his main competitors.

"The biggest challenge comes from comes from Gafa - Google, Amazon, Facebook and Apple. We are no longer just competing with banks," he said in an interview with 'Business Leader'. He said this was good for consumers, but very challenging for the incumbent banks.

"And I include ourselves in that. We are heavily regulated by the regulatory authorities. We have to hold a lot of capital. At the moment, the likes of Google and Amazon are not regulated and do not have to hold capital."

Big tech firms will benefit from the move to open banking.

Open banking will allow people to share their data across multiple suppliers and allow non-banks to say to customers that they could get a better value proposition than from the Bank of Ireland, Mr Crowley said.

"Most of us have banked with our current bank for a long time.

"Open banking will be prompting customers to say that they could get a better deal elsewhere.

"It is taking the aggregator model we have seen in financial services and further personalising banking." Mr Crowley revealed that Bank of Ireland UK has a balance sheet of £23bn ((EURO)26.18bn) and about 2.2 million customers.

It trades mainly in consumer markets such as deposits, mortgages, pre-paid debit cards, foreign exchange, and personal credit cards.

It provides banking services for the post office network in Britain.

"We cannot compete head on with the big six banks.

"We also don't want to be characterised in the same way as the other challenger and mid-tier banks."

He said the bank has distinctive position and that is why people knock on his door seeking a link-up.

Presentation

JILL HOMENUK, HEAD OF IR, BANK OF MONTREAL: Good morning, everybody. Thank you for joining us. I'm Jill Homenuk, Head of Investor Relations. We're happy to have you here with us for our 2018 All-Bank Investor Day. We have an action-packed agenda today with all of our businesses being covered and a number of our senior executives who are presenting today. In terms of the agenda, we're going to run until about 10 o'clock and then we're going to have about a 20-minute break and then we'll run until about noon after that. I also want to welcome our viewers on the webcast. Thank you also for joining us today.

On behalf of those speaking today, I'd like to note that forward-looking statements may be made during this presentation. Actual results could differ materially from forecast, projections or conclusions in these statements. I would also remind you that the bank uses non-GAAP financial measures to arrive at adjusted results. Management assesses its performance on both a reported and adjusted basis and considers both to be useful in assessing underlying business performance. Our presenters will generally be referring to adjusted results. Additional information on adjusting items, the bank's reported results and factors and assumptions related to forward-looking information can be found in our annual report and our third quarter report to shareholders. As a reminder, the Q&A portion is at the end of the agenda. So we would ask you to hold your questions until then. At that point, we will also be taking questions from the webcast.

Let's get started. Before I pass it over to our Chief Executive Officer, Darryl White, I'd like to show a short video. So if you could just please turn your attention to the screen.

(presentation)

WILLIAM DARRYL WHITE, CEO & DIRECTOR, BANK OF MONTREAL: Welcome, everyone, and thank you for joining us today here in the room and for those of you on the webcast as well. That video, as I watched it, reminded me of what an action-packed year it's been as we've continued to invest in our foundation. And today we're going to talk about how we pivot from that foundation into our future agenda.

So I've got 2 main objectives for the day. The first is to make sure that we're all clear on what's at the center of our priority list at the Bank of Montreal, what's at center ice for our executive team. And secondly, that you have the opportunity to get to know in further detail, in a lot of detail, frankly, our senior management team, my team of partners who are executing those strategies and delivering the results that we've talked about. I have had a lot of opportunity to spend time with most of you, frankly, over the course of the last couple of years. And today, you'll have the opportunity to spend a lot of time with all the leaders of the bank who are executing on those strategies.

Speaking of the team, we have had some exciting announcements, haven't we, in the last couple of weeks? Each of Surjit Rajpal and Gilles Ouellette have announced their intentions to retire in 2019. And we have announced that Surjit will be succeeded by Pat, who's here today, and Pat, in turn, will be succeeded by Dan Barclay, who is also here today. And when Gilles retires, Joanna Rotenberg will expand her current responsibilities beyond the Wealth Management businesses to the Global Asset Management businesses. We're excited about these changes. We take transition pretty seriously around here, and we've got a plan that will be absolutely flawless as we go through it.

I'm going to hit some of the key points. These are the key themes for the day. I'm going to hit the high points of what we call our strong foundation. I'm going to talk to you about why we believe we have truly differentiated strengths at the Bank of Montreal. And we're going to talk about how we're using those strengths to accelerate into the financial performance that we've been talking to about through the course of the year.

And as each of the presentations come up one by one, you'll see that they all ladder up to these key themes and to what we talk about as our One Bank, One Team, One Strategy approach.

A reset on the strategic priorities. A reminder on the strategic priorities that these haven't changed. And when we think about how we execute against these strategic priorities, we are now leaning in with an execution focus around operational excellence. And whether it's the customer experience, whether it's the digital innovation which we're going to hear a lot about today, the efficiency agenda which we're going to hear a lot about today, the North American platform and, of course, are tried and true risk management platform, in every case the lens that we're taking against the strategic priorities is one of a competitive mindset where we drive superior financial performance over the long run.

We spend a fair bit of time talking about the foundation. And this is for good reason. These on this slide are the bricks on which this house is built. We continue to invest in these bricks and we continue to invest in the house. I'm not going to touch down on all of them, but I will hit a couple of them to get us started here today. I'm going to start in the middle and build out.

When we talk about our diversified and attractive earnings mix, those are deliberate words, diversified and attractive. Diversified by geography. Diversified by business segment. We skew commercial. We skew U.S. relative to some of our peers. As far as our business segments are concerned geographically, if you look at our business, these are round numbers. We'll get into some more detail as we go through it. But you can think roughly about 60% of our income coming from Canada, close to 30% coming from the U.S., and about 10% coming internationally. 60/30/10, we like that mix. We think it sets us up well for the future and the environment that we're in right now. So a diversified and attractive earnings mix.

Top left, 8th largest bank in North America. Why does this matter? There are over 5,000 banks in North America. Bank of Montrealis the 8th largest bank in North America. We have the scale and we have the size to ensure that we're making the right investments at the right time in our digital agenda, in our technology agenda overall, in our regulatory agenda, in our brand spend, in our marketing spend overall. And this matters relative to many, many of the competitors that we've got in many of the markets that we deal in.

Below that, respected brand. Again, intentional language. The brand is really important. It's consistent everywhere we go. We've got a brand that's recognized whether we're here coast to coast in Canada or in Toronto, or if you went with me to Chicago or Milwaukee or Indianapolis or St. Louis or Minneapolis or our outer markets in Atlanta or in Ohio, for example, you would see that the brand is recognized and we continue to invest in it.

But we choose the word respected quite intentionally. And you'll see that come to life through the course of the presentations today. But one example of that I would give you right here, right now is that in the most recent American Banker awards, when American Banker did a study along with the Reputation Institute to source consumer opinion on the most respected bank brands in America, BMO's brand ranked #2 of the 40 largest banks in the United States as far as being respected. And that matters. And we think that that will matter a lot more as we go forward. By the way, #1 was USAA, so the bank to the U.S. military. So we're in pretty good company there.

Last one I'll hit on before I move off of this slide is consistent and effective risk management. Again, deliberate language, consistent and effective. We have been very good risk managers at the Bank of Montrealfor a very long time. It's important to say it. Our risk posture has not changed. Our risk appetite has not changed. We are challenging ourselves every day to make sure that where appropriate we execute and we operate at the full extent of our risk appetite. We are good risk managers in large part because we are very good relationship managers. And we manage risk with our clients through the cycle and we're continuing to manage risk with our clients through the cycle. And when we look back in 5 years from now, 10 years from now, 15 years from now, our objective is that we'll be able to do a look-back and say that all through the piece we will always have been considered world-class risk managers. It's a differentiated strength of the bank.

It's not the only differentiated strength of the bank; there are a number of others. When I go through these, I want you to know that we've been very thoughtful about thinking about and asking ourselves the question and asking some of you the question what makes BMO unique. What makes BMO unique? And I'll go through these in a little bit of detail, and I think you'll see them come to life through the various presentations that we've got going on through the morning today.

When we talk about a well-established U.S. presence, first transaction in the United States for the Bank of Montrealwas in 1818. We bought the Harris Bank in 1984. We've continually invested over time in our business in the United States. In 2010, 3% of the bank's earnings came from our U.S. operations. In 2011, 11% of the bank's earnings came from our U.S. operations. And year-to-date, as we told you, this year 28% of our earnings are coming from our U.S. operations. That's a mix we like. That's a mix that will continue to increase as we go forward.

Core strengths in commercial and wealth management. We're very proud of our core strengths in these businesses. You're going to hear from our leaders today. Joanna, Gilles will talk about wealth management. Our commercial bankers, you're going to hear from Dave. You're going to hear from a panel of commercial bankers who will talk to you about the work that we're doing on both sides of the border. We believe we're as good at the businesses as anybody that we compete with in any market, and we're proud of it and we're leaning in.

Unique approach to cross-border banking. Why do we talk about it as a unique approach? Because a lot of people do talk about cross-border banking, don't they? We are the only bank, best we can tell, that operates in every one of our lines of business, so whether it be personal banking, commercial banking, business banking, wholesale banking, capital markets, wealth management or asset management, on both sides of the border and do it in every case on an integrated basis.

Why does this matter? I'll give you a couple of examples. When we polled our wholesale customers and we asked them if they either currently are or intending to transact and do business on both sides of the U.S. border, 70% of them said that they were. We've been seeing stability in our savings business, which is important, and in our checking business. And we are starting to see some movement from some of our products, from a money market into a CD right now is what we're seeing in terms of a migration within the portfolio. We're seeing more pricing competition, no question about that, and so we're looking at how do we diversify the play in the portfolio and take advantage of opportunities in certain markets where we think we can price differently and to different customer segments. So a generally macro statement would say that there is more of a shift in terms of getting back to the customer more of the increase, but it's managing that portfolio, and that's what our plans are and have been, and we've been doing that quite effectively.

WILLIAM DARRYL WHITE: I'd just add on the commercial side, we're -- as you recall, we're underweight commercial deposits versus -- in the U.S. versus retail, and we're overweight the loans for commercial. But on the commercial deposits, we're up overall, but there absolutely has been a shift, and we would expect -- these commercial clients, they watch. They're sophisticated treasurers. They're going to expect from their bank, and we would do that, that we would pay up and there would be a change over time. What we've seen, though, and what we've been successful at is gathering -- we always have the deposits of our commercial clients where they are running all their cash through us. We're their cash management bank. That's good business for us. Also, we don't always have, but we have been more aggressive in getting the cash, the excess cash, from those clients and from prospects, so that would also help -- that'll build our deposits, but it would be a little bit more interest-bearing. It's what you would expect in a rising rate environment. It's not a big surprise for us, and we want to always stay competitive but have the full relationship of those clients as well. That help?

WILLIAM DARRYL WHITE: We had another hand up a moment ago over here. I don't see it currently. It's coming back around. Gabriel, then Ralph.

GABRIEL DECHAINE: A couple follow-ups here on the businesses. In the commercial bank, in the U.S., the loan growth we've seen has been really, really strong, and, thankfully, it doesn't look to be a 1-trick pony driven by commercial real estate. But to play devil's advocate, I see pretty much all the U.S. banks generating sub-5% commercial growth or talking about intensification of competition from non-banks and what have you. So why shouldn't I be worried about seeing growth like the kind you're delivering in the commercial loan book, and why should I be comfortable with it? Just to play devil's advocate.

WILLIAM DARRYL WHITE: No, no, it's a great question and 1 that I think we address every day. We're not worried, but we're always watching to see that, so we've got a couple of things. Very diversified -- our real estate business is less than 10%, and a lot of the banks are a lot larger, so they're pulling back. What we've done, though, and what we've tried to show is in these specialty businesses -- and when we talk about them, asset-based lending is a good example. Our floor plan business is another good example. As we've grown, we've gotten to scale. We've kind of caught up with other banks. These are businesses too that have underlying assets behind them. So when there is a downturn, you still have the asset. You have a truck, you have receivables and inventory, so these are businesses that have very low losses given to fall. Where we haven't grown specifically in any major way is in the riskiest businesses we have. We have them, but they're a smaller part. So I feel real good about it. I feel that when I do see -- and I watch all the U.S. reporting, and I see lots of things that people talk about. We have paydowns every quarter. We compete with all of the non-banks. But I think we've found a way -- and I will point back to this group over here -- of not competing on risk, presenting a good long-term value, and growing over the long term, and that's the message we have. We started this in 2010 to say this is going to be a good business in the U.S. and we should double down to grow it, and so I feel really good about it. And we had low losses. They'll go up at some point, but I do not feel that we are creating a good problem.

WILLIAM DARRYL WHITE: Gabriel, I would just add, before we go to Rob, unless -- do you have 2 parts of your question?

GABRIEL DECHAINE: I have a follow-up.

WILLIAM DARRYL WHITE: I'm going to follow up on the follow-up, and you can follow up. I would just add, in a way that perhaps Dave won't, that we're really, really good at this business. When we look at our commercial franchise and the DNA that's been built up effectively over the course of 35 years, we're -- this business we think -- by the way, there's a little bit sketchy -- a little bit of sketchy data on this, but when we look at the commercial definition of the -- traditional definition of the commercial market, BMO is the seventh largest commercial lender in the United States. We think they're the second largest commercial lender in Canada. When you put it together, in North America, we're inside of 7. So we don't take a back seat to anybody in terms of our relationship capability, and yet the reason I think it's a sweet spot is that, while we're the seventh largest commercial lender in the United States, we still have low aggregate market share. We've got really leading capabilities and an ability to beat anybody in a street fight or in a boardroom to get the business, but we have a low market share. So we are taking share, and we're taking it from folks who are pretty good competitors, and Dave's team is doing a really good job of it. It's actually not a lot more complicated than that, but it's hard to get there.

GABRIEL DECHAINE: The next 1 is, I guess, for Dave on the capital market side, also U.S.-related. So the extension of the balance sheet has been a big part of that story, corporate lending. I'm just wondering -- that's the backdrop, I guess. How do you see -- or what are the main drivers to get you from your 70%-plus efficiency ratio you're at these days to 60% or below, your 5-year target? Are you happy with the ancillary revenue generation that you've achieved with that balance sheet that you put out there, or are you progressing ahead as normal, or are you reviewing the relationships? What's the progress like now?

WILLIAM DARRYL WHITE: Well, I think you've answered my question, which is nice. The driver for us is going to be scale in a bunch of this, and the lending book is a really interesting 1. If you remember -- sitting up here a few years ago, we would have told you we were a mid-market strategy. The mid-market, really, for us when we think about it, corporate versus commercial, was clients in the $100 million, $250 million, $500 million range. Then we stretched it to $2 billion, then to $5 billion, and now we'd tell you we're stretching it to $10 billion. And so what we're doing is we're increasing scale. One of the benefits of that is we're actually moving more into the investment grade than we were before. We had that cusp B, BBB, as kind of a core strength, and now we're really stretching that quite a bit broader, and so we're doing bigger loans, we're doing it with better clients, higher credit quality clients, and that's an underpinning. That business runs for us very similar to commercial, kind of in the mid-30s in terms of efficiency. Investment banking runs higher. Trading runs higher. And so we get to a blend of businesses is what's going to bring us down. The second is when you think about us moving forward in terms of revenue growth, I made lots of references to scale. We put a lot of investment into the business -- regulatory is a great example -- where you have to have a core capability on AML to survive, right? That's a basic service offering. As you think about doubling your revenues from where we are -- I don't need to double that regulatory scale anymore, right? I don't need to double the number of people we have in trading products. I don't need to double the number of people we have in banking to double our share. I'm going to add share in lots of places, which really flows down into net income. And so if you think about it in the classic operating leverage, we're going to increase revenues faster than expenses. That's what we're going to do. In all places, we're going to be increasing our expenses. It's just revenue will be faster.

WILLIAM DARRYL WHITE: Rob, you were trying to get in.

ROBERT SEDRAN, MD & HEAD OF RESEARCH, CIBC CAPITAL MARKETS, RESEARCH DIVISION: It's Rob Sedran from CIBC. Cam, for you on the mortgage business. And candidly, I'm not concerned about risk in the answer, so feel free to go there if you like, but it's more about growth. So we know that the market has clearly slowed, and I think I saw the word aggressive on your slide in terms of adding sales, sales staff, so a little bit more color on what you're hoping to achieve in what feels like a late cycle in the housing market, at least from a growth perspective. And then around the same issue, we've historically thought -- and maybe we've overused the word anchor, but we've historically thought of the anchor product as the mortgage product, and so if that's not the anchor product anymore, what's the anchor product of tomorrow that's going to get you the 1 million in net new customers you're looking for?

CAMERON FOWLER: So the first thing that I would say on the mortgage side, we made the participation choice 7, 8, 9 years ago to not be part of the broker market. So everything we do, we originate by ourselves, and we are very limited participants in the third-party part as well. So we start from that position that says we have a strong capability in this regard, we have a strong branch footprint, but in terms -- as you saw from the page, in terms of the number of mortgage specialists on the street we have right now, we've got a number that is in the 500 range. Obviously, we have FSMs and other folks in the branch who do this as well. That's a number that's meaningfully lower than our peer group. You put with that the fact that we have a wonderfully healthy book that we're super proud of and confident in, but it is smaller relative to the peers. So, to us, I think the fundamental point is that the opportunity is bigger. I would say that market down 15-ish and in the 20s in GTA and GVA, but settling the rest of the Canada market outside of those 2 things is relatively healthy and relatively well balanced, and so we see there to be opportunities outside of the 2 big markets where we're strong, but not performing as well as we could in this product. You're right to say that there can be other anchor products in terms of growth, and when we think about a net million, we're pretty focused on primary, and for us primary is checking, and specifically the checking where the relationship involves the deposit of the paycheck. And so a lot of our energy will go to ensuring that we can acquire checking accounts via digital in as high a quality way as we do via the branch channel, and that specifically means doing more than 1 product when you do so to secure the relationship. But if you were to say is there a co-anchor idea, like the ones you met earlier on stage today, mortgage and checking I think are reasonable ways to think about it.

ROBERT SEDRAN: It is fair to assume, though, that the mortgage product is still part of that million net new, is taking share in the mortgage product.

CAMERON FOWLER: Yes, I expect that we would take a little bit. It is not -- winning and that alone is not the ambition. We'll be out or ahead of market, and I think you'll see that in the next couple of quarters. We probably already are, but we're not looking to -- that's what we're looking to do.

WILLIAM DARRYL WHITE: We probably have time for 1 more, maybe 2, depending on the complexity of Sumit's question.

SUMIT MALHOTRA: My question is actually for someone not onstage. That's Pat, if he's still around.

WILLIAM DARRYL WHITE: Pat is over here.

SUMIT MALHOTRA: So Pat -- well, first off, Surjit is doing a really good job as Chief Risk Officer.

WILLIAM DARRYL WHITE: Surjit is over here.

SUMIT MALHOTRA: He's leaving when things are perfect, so he's --

WILLIAM DARRYL WHITE: I couldn't agree more.

SUMIT MALHOTRA: -- handing the baton over to you. So as incoming Chief Risk Officer, you hear your commercial colleagues talking about double-digit growth. In U.S. personal, we're talking about increased growth in credit cards and auto, which historically have been higher loss rate products in the U.S. You're a markets guy. Equity market doesn't seem to be as sanguine about credit as most of the banks I talk to or hear from do. So when you put all these things together, what are some of the factors, as the Chief Risk Officer, that you would look at, either qualitatively or quantitatively, to make you go to your colleagues and say we've got to rethink some of these growth objectives that we've put out to the market today?

PATRICK CRONIN: Well, I'll say for starters, now you have me really worried about taking on this job. I would say, first of all, it's probably a little bit too early for me to answer the question. I can tell you a little bit of my philosophy going in, though. And I think even though I am a markets guy by background, probably 1 of the things I'm most proud of in my career is, amongst other people in the business, really building up a strong risk management capability in capital markets. We've spent the better part of 5 to 10 years investing heavily in the risk infrastructure and the risk culture, and so that's the philosophy that I'm bringing into the role, that that really is the foundation for all of the strategies that my colleagues are talking about. And so if we don't continue to invest heavily, continue to focus really deeply on the risk -- a lot of the same risk metrics you're talking about, we're going to undermine the strategies of all of my colleagues, so you can expect the same level of risk discipline. Secondly, I would simply point to my second strategy, which is a continuation really of what's been going on in the risk group so far. I think several of my colleagues have pointed to our track record over the past 5 years or so across all kinds of risk metrics, whether you look at PCLs, whether you look at our VAR or stress exposure in the risk groups, our operational risk track record, our track record in regulatory reviews and audits. And so my primary goal in the first 6 to 12 months is going to be to maintain the stability of that group and continue the great risk management tradition that we've got right now. So then over the course of time, I'll start to develop views along with the risk team about some of the key metrics that I want to look at to help underpin the strategies, but I think it's too early for me to say which ones are going to be the drivers of my thought process. We've got a lot of great risk professionals that I'll rely on that before that happens.

WILLIAM DARRYL WHITE: One thing I can tell you -- and it might be a good place to end it -- is that I've worked with Patrick for a very long time, and if there's anybody who has a great way of coming in either the front door or the back door and saying you probably shouldn't do that, it's Pat, and he will do an excellent job in this role, and he'll follow a superb job that Surjit has done in making sure with his team, with a great team, that we're all taking care of the risks at the same time as we take care of the customers. So we've got that at center ice as well. If I don't -- I don't see any other hands, so I'm going to do an attempt at wrapping up. We're going to get you out of this room before noon sharp, and I'd like to just leave you with a couple of thoughts. I was sitting listening to the presentations today, thinking to myself if I was in your shoes and you were to take away what's new -- you'll formulate your own point of view on this, but I was looking at the various commentary that we heard today. Some of the financial goals are new. We've been specific with respect to the achievement of the 58% in 3 years through the 2% of operating leverage. We've been specific with respect to the 1/3 from the U.S. We've been specific with respect to our spend on the technology agenda. On the technology agenda, the digital leadership that we talked to you about today I said at the beginning I thought might come as a bit of a surprise to some. You'll see a few more surprises if you've got some time to join us. When you leave the room, we're going to serve lunch, and then if you keep going to your left, we've got quite a display of technology innovations that we've got going on in the digital side, including some robots that are wandering around that you can talk to and do some fun things with. So I think there's a lot of exciting things from my perspective that are new on the digital agenda. When Luke was talking about the EI3 agenda, this is brand new. We got going on this only 8 months ago, so we're really only ramping up speed towards the efficiencies that Luke was talking about, and that'll be really productive for all of our employees, our customers and our shareholders. And the other thing that was particularly inspiring to me is as I watched the different groups perform what I like to think about as the 1 bank, 1 team, 1 strategy, it was remarkable for me to hear Ray, a U.S. commercial banker, talking about trucking clients in the United States and our businesses in commercial talking about 53% increase in referral rates to wealth and 23% referral increases to capital markets, and the list goes on and on as -- whether we're talking cross-border, cross-function or cross-business. This is for real, and this is what's happening here, and I wouldn't say to you that that's brand new. We've been at this for quite a while, but I can say to you that I think we're at an inflection point where everybody is in it together and everybody's got a hand on the oar, and I'm very proud of the work that we've done in that capacity. Before we wrap up, 1 shout out. This has been a great session today. Thank you for all of your attention. As we think about our relationships with the investment community, analysts, shareholders, rating agencies, there's 1 person in the room that I didn't give a shout out to earlier, and that's Frank Teacher. And Frank is sitting in the front row, and Frank probably, if there were an award for somebody who has spent more time being an ambassador for this bank -- probably went through 40 or 50 or 60 quarterly analyst calls where you heard his voice. You didn't have the pleasure always of seeing his smiling face through the whole way. I just want to give a shout out to Frank, because Frank will be moving on to his retirement in 2019, and he has been the best partner to all of us that are up here, and he's been a best partner to the investment community as well. So it just occurs to me that this may be the last time that he's here with all of you in person at the same time, so I'd like to give Frank some applause. And afterwards, Frank is going to be sure to take us aside and tell us everything that we should have done better, and that's good too. But now my responsibility is to get you out of the room. So for those of you who are here in the room, join us, as I said, for lunch in the tech showcase, so you just keep following around to your left. For those of you on the webcast, thank you for joining us today. We're out of time. We look forward to talk to you all again soon. Thanks.

urn:contentItem:5X39-J291-DY1R-B05N-00000-00Bank of Spain believes Pound could destabilize economy2019-09-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:16ZLexisNexisBank of Spain believes Pound could destabilize economy


The deputy governor of the Bank of Spain, Margarita Delgado, warned that Libra, the virtual currency that Facebook is going to launch, "could become a destabilizing element of the economy."


"The potential consequences are of such magnitude that we must maintain all kinds of caution," Delgado warned during his participation in the II Banking Forum "The banking sector in the face of the challenge of digitization".
Among the risks that this currency has highlighted consumer protection, since, he said, the contractual agreements that will determine Libra's behavior are not "transparent enough" for users to understand the risks well those who are exposed.
The deputy governor of the Bank of Spain also called for "neutral, fair and symmetrical" regulation for large technology companies, so-called bigtech, that allows innovation to move forward and ensure "equal opportunities" with banking Traditional.
The challenge is great and growing with the advent of bigtechs—big tech companies like Facebook, Google, or Amazon—which are a disruption factor that contributes to adding more pressure, which you can't "stay out of," he said.

The deputy governor of the Bank of Spain, Margarita Delgado, has warned that Libra, the currency that Facebook and other investors are going to launch, "could become a destabilizing element of the economy".


"The potential consequences are of such magnitude that we must maintain all kinds of caution,"Delgado warned during his participation in the II Banking Forum "The Banking Sector In the Face of the Challenge of Digitization".
Among the risks that this currency has highlighted the protection of consumers, since, he has said, the contractual agreements that will determine Libra's behavior are not "transparent enough" for users understand the risks to which they are exposed.
'Biigtech'
The deputy governor of the Bank of Spain has also called for "neutral, fair and symmetrical" regulation for large technology companies,the so-called "bigtech", that allows innovation to move forward and ensure "equal opportunities" with the traditional banking.
The challenge "is great" and increases with the advent of "bigtech" - big tech companies such as Facebook, Google or Amazon- which are a disruption factor that contributes to adding more pressure, which you can't "stay out of," has Said.
The phenomenon has two sides, on the one hand it can contribute to expanding the supply of financial services and improve innovation and access levels and on the other hand it harbors "countless risks",which can even have a "systemic" character .
Data
Delgado has also insisted that the banking sector needs to reinvent itself to remain relevant, a challenge in which it highlights "above all" the importance of data.
"The future of the banking business is the access, management and exploitation of the information available in order to capitalize on the competitive advantages presented by the sector," he said.

urn:contentItem:60GB-HGJ1-JC11-1030-00000-00Bank Policy Institute: Banking and Consumer Groups Call on Congress to Close ILC Loophole2020-07-30T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:18:16ZLexisNexisBank Policy Institute: Banking and Consumer Groups Call on Congress to Close ILC LoopholeTargeted News ServiceWASHINGTON

The Bank Policy Institute issued the following news release:

The Bank Policy Institute (BPI), Center for Responsible Lending (CRL) and Independent Community Bankers of America (ICBA) urged Congress to impose a three-year moratorium on industrial loan company licensing applications. The moratorium on Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation approvals would provide Congress time to close the ILC loophole and ensure ILCs and their parent companies don't pose unnecessary risks to consumers and taxpayers.

"ILCs offer banking products and services that are functionally indistinguishable from those offered by banks, but the ILC loophole allows the parent companies of ILCs to avoid oversight by the Federal Reserve Board and to engage in commercial activities, thus introducing risk to the banking system and to taxpayers," the groups wrote. "Legislative action to close this loophole is necessary to eliminate these risks."

ILCs are FDIC-insured, state-chartered institutions that can generally engage in the full range of banking activities, such as taking deposits and making loans. But unlike banks, their parent companies are not subject to the Bank Holding Company Act, which means those companies are not subject to any federal supervision, regulations or standards. For this reason, there has historically been considerable opposition to the charter, and both Congress and the FDIC have placed temporary moratoria on ILCs.

Big Tech company ownership of an ILC introduces a new concern: that consumer data, including sensitive personal financial information, will be inadequately safeguarded and used in inappropriate and unauthorized ways. With global e-commerce giant Rakuten recently joining tech firms such as Square and Nelnet in applying to form ILCs, the risk associated with this legal loophole is greater than ever.

"In the era of dominant Big Tech, we should be cautious before giving technology companies even greater reach into the economic life of Americans by allowing them to own banks," the groups wrote. "The integration of technology and banking firms would not only result in an enormous concentration of financial and technological assets but also would pose conflicts of interest and privacy concerns to our banking system."

The groups further noted, "A growth in ILCs poses broader consumer protection risks as well, because non-bank lenders, including very high-cost lenders, view the ILC charter as a far easier way to obtain banking privileges than obtaining a traditional bank charter and, consequently, becoming subject to consolidated Federal Reserve supervision."

In March, the FDIC issued a notice of proposed rulemaking related to parent companies of industrial banks and industrial loan companies. BPI, CRL, ICBA and a coalition of civil rights groups wrote to the FDIC requesting that the FDIC not approve ILC deposit insurance applications until its ILC rulemaking is final. However, in recent months, the FDIC has approved some ILC applications and is reviewing others, including some whose parent companies engage in commercial activities.
